137  // Most of the aln_filter.cpp can be rewritten in terms of
138  // fn::compose, but looking at the diff of the code I'm not
139  // convinced this provides a lot of added value, although it
140  // obviates the need in operator%.
141  //
142  // With operator % we are passing results from one function to
143  // another through a chain of invocations.
144  // With fn::compose we are creating a "template centipede" instead.
145  //
146  // Also, with point-free approach we can't specify
147  // input and output types and can't give it a name
148  // to the input, so even though point-free is shorter,
149  // it is not necessarily easier to reason about.
150  //
151  // Disabling for now; may rething later.
152 
153  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
154  template<typename F, typename G>
155  struct composed
156  {
157  F f;
158  G g;
159 
160  template<typename X>
161  auto operator()(X&& x) & -> decltype(g(f(std::forward<X>(x))))
162  {
163  return g(f(std::forward<X>(x)));
164  }
165 
166  // some operations can be rvalue-specific, e.g. foldl::operator()
167  template<typename X>
168  auto operator()(X&& x) && -> decltype(std::move(g)(std::move(f)(std::forward<X>(x))))
169  {
170  return std::move(g)(std::move(f)(std::forward<X>(x)));
171  }
172  };
173 
174  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
175 
176  template<typename... T>
177  struct composed_type_builder;
178 
179  template<typename F, typename G>
180  struct composed_type_builder<F, G>
181  {
182  using type = impl::composed<F, G>;
183  };
184 
185  template<typename F, typename G, typename... Rest>
186  struct composed_type_builder<F, G, Rest...>
187  {
188  using type = typename composed_type_builder<impl::composed<F, G>, Rest...>::type;
189  };
190 
191  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
192 }
193 
194  template<typename F, typename G>
195  auto compose(F f, G g) -> impl::composed<F, G>
196  {
197  return { std::move(f), std::move(g) };
198  }
199 
200  template<typename F, typename G, typename... Rest>
201  auto compose(F f, G g, Rest... fns)
202 #if __cplusplus >= 201406L
203  // in c++14 return-type is auto-deduced
204 #elif 0
205  // This produces compilation error with 4 or more args
206  // (e.g. my::where_min_by in aln_filter.cpp). Not sure why.
207  -> decltype(compose(impl::composed<F,G>{ std::move(f), std::move(g) }, std::move(fns)...))
208 #else
209  // As a work-around, will compute the type manually using composed_type_builder metafunction
210  -> typename impl::composed_type_builder<F, G, Rest...>::type
211 #endif
212  {
213  return compose(impl::composed<F,G>{ std::move(f), std::move(g) }, std::move(fns)...);
214  }

232  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
233  /// Very bare-bones version of std::optional-like with rebinding assignment semantics.
234  template<class T>
235  class maybe
236  {
237  struct sentinel{};
238  union
239  {
240  sentinel m_sentinel;
241  T m_value;
242  };
243 
244  bool m_empty = true;
245 
246  public:
247  using value_type = T;
248 
249  maybe() : m_sentinel{}
250  {}
251 
252  // to avoid double-destruction
253  maybe(const maybe&) = delete;
254  maybe& operator=(const maybe&) = delete;
255 
256  maybe(T val)
257  {
258  reset(std::move(val));
259  }
260 
261  maybe(maybe&& other) noexcept
262  { //^^ by value instead?
263  if(!other.m_empty) {
264  reset(std::move(*other));
265  other.reset();
266  }
267  }
268 
269  // need this for monadic binding?
270  // maybe(maybe<maybe<T>> other) noexcept { ... }
271 
272 
273  // NB: the assignment semantics differ from that of std::optional!
274  // See discussion in reset() below
275  maybe& operator=(maybe&& other) noexcept
276  {
277  if(this == &other) {
278  ;
279  } else if(!other.m_empty) {
280  reset(std::move(*other));
281  other.reset();
282  } else {
283  reset();
284  }
285  return *this;
286  }
287 
288  void reset(T val)
289  {
290  // NB: even if we are holding a value, we don't move-assign to it
291  // and instead reset and place-new, because the type may be
292  // move-constructible but not move-assigneable, e.g. containing a closure.
293  // https://stackoverflow.com/questi ons/38541354/move-assignable-lambdas-in-clang-and-gcc/
294  //
295  // Another reason we can't simply move-assign to
296  // is that T may be a tuple containing
297  // references, and we want to assign maybe<T> of such tuple
298  // without assigning referenced objects as a side-effect,
299  // unlike std::optional: (See NB[2])
300  // int x = 42;
301  // int y = 99;
302  // std::optional<std::tuple<int&>> opt_x = std::tie(x);
303  // std::optional<std::tuple<int&>> opt_y = std::tie(y);
304  // opt_x = opt_y; // x is now 99 - Why, c++ standard committee? whyyyy??
305  //
306  // For our purposes maybe<T> should behave similarly
307  // to a unique_ptr, except with stack-storage, where
308  // reassignment simply transfers ownership.
309  //
310  // Related:
311  // http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg21/docs/papers/2013/n3527.html#optional_ref.rationale.assign
312  // https://www.fluentcpp.com/2018/10/05/pros-cons-optional-references/
313 
314  reset();
315 
316  new (&m_value) T(std::move(val));
317 
318  m_empty = false;
319  }
320 
321  void reset()
322  {
323  if(!m_empty) {
324  this->operator*().~T();
325  m_empty = true;
326  }
327  }
328 
329  explicit operator bool() const noexcept
330  {
331  return !m_empty;
332  }
333 
334  T& operator*() noexcept
335  {
336  assert(!m_empty);
337 
338 #if __cplusplus >= 201703L
339  return std::launder(m_value);
340 #else
341  return m_value;
342 #endif
343  }
344 
345  // I believe technically we need std::launder here, yet I couldn't
346  // find a single implementation of `optional` that launders
347  // memory after placement-new, or side-steps the issue.
348  //
349  // https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/types/aligned_storage (static_vector example)
350  // https://github.com/ericniebler/range-v3
351  // https://github.com/mpark/base
352  // https://github.com/akrzemi1/Optional
353  // https://github.com/TartanLlama/optional
354  // https://github.com/ned14/outcome (MVP for discussing the issue in the documentation)
355  //
356  // We'll formally test for expected behavior in a unit-test.
357 
358  const T& operator*() const noexcept
359  {
360  assert(!m_empty);
361 
362 #if __cplusplus >= 201703L
363  return std::launder(m_value);
364 #else
365  return m_value;
366 #endif
367  }

385  ~maybe()
386  {
387  reset();
388  }

392 #if 0
393  // in the future will get rid of <deque> dependency
394  // and will use our own simple bounded queue.
395  template<typename T>
396  class queue
397  {
398  public:
399  queue(size_t capacity)
400  : m_capacity{ capacity }
401  {
402  m_data.reserve(capacity);
403  }
404 
405  void push(T x)
406  {
407  if(m_beg + m_capacity >= m_end) {
408  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Queue is full");
409 
410  } else if(m_data.size() < m_capacity) {
411  m_data.push_back(std::move(x));
412  ++m_end;
413 
414  } else {
415  m_data[m_end++ % m_capacity] = std::move(x);
416  }
417  }
418 
419  T pop()
420  {
421  if(m_beg >= m_end) {
422  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Queue is empty");
423  }
424  return std::move(m_data[m_beg++ % m_capacity]);
425  }
426 
427  size_t size() const
428  {
429  return m_end - m_beg;
430  }
431 
432  bool empty() const
433  {
434  return m_beg == m_end;
435  }
436 
437  std::vector<T> as_vec() &&
438  {
439  // rotate the elements to put oldest at front
440  return m_data;
441  }

443  class iterator
444  {
445  public:
446  using iterator_category = std::random_access_iterator_tag;
447  using difference_type = ptrdiff_t;
448  using value_type = T;
449  using pointer = value_type*;
450  using reference = value_type&;
451 
452  iterator();
453  iterator(const iterator&) = default;
454  iterator& operator=(const iterator&) = default;
455 
456  pointer operator->() const;
457  reference operator*() const;
458 
459  iterator& operator++();
460  iterator operator++(int);
461 
462  iterator& operator--();
463  iterator operator--(int);
464 
465  iterator& operator+=(difference_type n)
466  {
467  assert(m_pos + n <= m_parent.m_end);
468  m_pos += n;
469  return *this;
470  }
471 
472  iterator& operator-=(difference_type n)
473  {
474  assert(m_beg + n <= m_pos);
475  m_pos -= n;
476  return *this;
477  }
478 
479  iterator operator+(difference_type n) const;
480  iterator operator-(difference_type n) const;
481 
482  bool operator==(const iterator& other) const;
483  bool operator!=(const iterator& other) const;
484  bool operator<(const iterator& other) const;
485 
486  private:
487  queue& m_parent;
488  size_t m_pos;
489  };
490 
491 
492  private:
493  using vec_t = std::vector<T>;
494 
495  const size_t m_capacity;
496  size_t m_beg = 0;
497  size_t m_end = 0;
498  std::vector<T> m_data = {};
499  };
500 #endif

538  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
539  // adapter for unary sink-functions
540  template<typename SinkFn>
541  class output_iterator
542  {
543  public:
544  using iterator_category = std::output_iterator_tag;
545  using difference_type = void;
546  using value_type = void;
547  using pointer = void;
548  using reference = void;
549 
550  output_iterator& operator++() { return *this; }
551  output_iterator& operator*() { return *this; }
552 
553  template<typename T>
554  output_iterator& operator=(T&& inp)
555  {
556  (*sink)(std::forward<T>(inp));
557  return *this;
558  }
559 
560 #if 0
561  // In MSVC lambdas are copy-constructible but not copy-assignable,
562  // so copy-assignment is implicitly deleted because of SinkFn field.
563  //
564  // std::copy in MSVC relies on output-iterator being copy-assignable
565  // under the hood, so we need to implement copy-assignment via
566  // placement-new. I'm not 100% sure this is legit, however.
567  output_iterator& operator=(const output_iterator& other)
568  {
569  if(this != &other) {
570  sink.~sink();
571  new (&sink) SinkFn(other.sink);
572  }
573  return *this;
574  }
575  output_iterator(const output_iterator&) = default;
576 
577  output_iterator(output_iterator&&) = default;
578  output_iterator& operator=(output_iterator&&) = default;
579 
580  // By the way, I looked at <boost/function_output_iterator.hpp>.
581  // It just holds SinkFn by value and suffers from the same issue,
582  // (since 2001) https://godbolt.org/z/-5ORiK
583 #else
584  // Thinking more about it, I think just holding sink_fn by
585  // shared_ptr is a better approach, having all copies
586  // of the output_iterator refer to the same sink object.
587  //
588  // requires #include <memory>, adding 0.05s to #includes-overhead,
589  // which is heavy-ish.
590 
591  std::shared_ptr<SinkFn> sink;
592 #endif
593  };

595  /// Adapt unary sink-function as output iterator. @see generate
596  template<typename SinkFn>
597  static output_iterator<SinkFn> make_output_iterator(SinkFn sink_fn)
598  {
599  return { std::make_shared<SinkFn>( std::move(sink_fn) ) };
600  }
601 #endif

606  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
607  /// @brief Return fn::end_seq() from input-range generator function to signal end-of-inputs.
608  ///
609  /// This throws fn::end_seq::exception on construction, and is interpreted internally as end-of-inputs.
610  /// This exception does not propagate outside of the API's boundaries.
611  struct end_seq
612  {
613  // First I called it just "end", but want to avoid name confusion, because
614  // end() usually returns end-iterator in c++.
615 
616  /* I chose to allow exception-based approach to singal end-of-inputs.
617  *
618  * This is a pythonic approach to signal end-of-inputs from a generator function.
619  * This is cleanest from the API perspective, allowing for very trivial
620  * custom logic with fn::adapt, and also most straightforward under the hood
621  * implementation-wise. Using exceptions for flow control is generally
622  * considered a bad idea, but since the API is exeception-neutral, the
623  * only downside from the external perspective is the overhead
624  * associated with exceptional code path).
625  *
626  * Update: Switched the internals to monadic end-of-seq signaling by passing values
627  * via maybe-wrapper everywhere. To allow easy usage to user-code if they
628  * can tolerate exception-handling overhead, the user-code gen-function is wrapped
629  * in catch_end callable that will catch the end_seq::exception and will return
630  * empty-maybe, adapting the gen-function from exception-based to empty-maybe representation.
631  */
632 
633  struct exception
634  {};
635 
636  // TODO: can we preallocate exception with std::make_exception_ptr
637  // and then reuse it with std::rethrow_exception, which would avoid
638  // allocation? This doesn't seem to make any difference on throughput, however.
639  //
640  // Related article on performance of exceptions:
641  // http://nibblestew.blogspot.com/2017/01/measuring-execution-performance-of-c.html
642 
643 
644  // throw on construction or in conversion?
645  // There are pros and cons, i.e.
646  // a user may simply do `fn::end_seq();`
647  // and expect it to take effect.
648  //
649  // Also,
650  // return cond ? ret : fn::end_seq();
651  // will prevent copy-elision, one has to remember to std::move(ret).
652  end_seq()
653  {
654  throw exception{};
655  }
656 
657 #if 0 // MSVC 19.15 does not support noreturn
658  template<typename T>
659  [[ noreturn ]] operator T() const
660  {
661  throw exception{};
662  }
663 #else
664  template<typename T>
665  operator T() const
666  {
667  throw exception{};
668  return std::move(*impl::maybe<T>{});
669  }
670 #endif
671 
672  };
673 
674 
675 
676 namespace impl
677 {
678  // will isolate exception-based end-of-seq signaling and will
679  // not throw end_seq::exception ourselves (except in adapt,
680  // if user-code calls gen() past-the-end) to allow nonthrowing functionality.
681  template<typename Gen>
682  struct catch_end
683  {
684  Gen gen;
685  bool ended; // after first end_seq::exception
686  // will return empty-maybe without invoking gen, to avoid
687  // repeating the exception-handling overhead.
688 
689  using value_type = decltype(gen());
690 
691  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
692  {
693  if(ended) {
694  return { };
695  }
696 
697  try {
698  return { gen() };
699  } catch( const end_seq::exception& ) {
700  ended = true;
701  return { };
702  }
703  }
704  };

711  {
712  gen.recycle(value);
713  }

715  // Low-priority fallback when gen.recycle(...) is not viable.
716  template<typename G, typename T>
717  void recycle(G&, T&, pr_low)
718  {
719  // no-op
720  }

735 
736  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
737  /// Single-pass InputRange-adapter for nullary generators.
738  ///
739  template<typename Gen>
740  class seq
741  {
742  // NB: This yields rvalue-references (`reference = value_type&&`)
743  // Pros:
744  // 1) If the downstream function takes arg by value (e.g. to transform, for_each, foldl, etc),
745  // it will be passed without making a copy.
746  //
747  // 2) We want to prevent user-code from making lvalue-references
748  // to the iterator's value, that will be invalidated when the iterator is incremented.
749  //
750  // Cons: move-iterators are not widely used, and an expression like `auto x = *it;`
751  // leaves *it in moved-from state, and it may not be clear from the context that a move just happened.
752  // That said, the entire point of this library is so that the user-code does not
753  // need to deal with iterators directly.
754 
755  public:
756  using value_type = typename get_value_type<Gen>::type;
757  static_assert(!std::is_reference<value_type>::value, "The type returned by the generator-function must be a value-type. Use std::ref if necessary.");
758 
759  seq(Gen gen)
760  : m_gen( std::move(gen) ) // NB: must use parentheses here!
761  {}
762 
763  // To support conversion to any_seq_t.
764  // (i.e. Gen is a std::function, and OtherGen is some-lambda-type)
765  //
766  // Used to implement as rvalue-specific implicit conversion,
767  // using any_seq_t = seq<std::function<impl::maybe<value_type>()>>;
768  // operator any_seq_t() && { ... }
769  //
770  // but can't do this because of MSVC bug
771  // causing ambiguous overload resolution vs.
772  // operator std::vector<value_type>() &&
773  template<typename OtherGen>
774  seq(seq<OtherGen> other)
775  : m_current{ std::move(other.m_current) }
776  , m_gen{ std::move(other.m_gen) }
777  , m_started{ other.m_started }
778  , m_ended{ other.m_ended }
779  , m_resumable{ other.m_resumable }
780 
781  {
782  other.m_started = true;
783  other.m_ended = true;
784  }
785 
786  seq(const seq&) = delete;
787  seq& operator=(const seq&) = delete;
788 
789  seq(seq&&) = default;
790  seq& operator=(seq&&) = default;
791 
792  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
793  class iterator
794  {
795  public:
796  using iterator_category = std::input_iterator_tag;
797  using difference_type = void;
798  using value_type = seq::value_type;
799  using pointer = value_type*;
800  using reference = value_type&&; // NB: rvalue-reference
801 
802  iterator(seq* p = nullptr) : m_parent{ p }
803  {}
804 
805  iterator& operator++()
806  {
807  if(!m_parent || m_parent->m_ended) {
808  m_parent = nullptr;
809  return *this;
810  }
811 
812  auto& p = *m_parent;
813 
814  if(p.m_current) {
815  impl::recycle(p.m_gen, *p.m_current, resolve_overload{});
816  }
817 
818  p.m_current = p.m_gen();
819 
820  if(!p.m_current) {
821  p.m_ended = true;
822  m_parent = nullptr; // reached end
823  }
824  return *this;
825  }
826 
827 #pragma GCC diagnostic push
828 #pragma GCC diagnostic ignored "-Weffc++" // insists operator++(int) should be returning iterator
829  maybe<value_type> operator++(int) // to support *it++ usage
830  {
831  auto ret = std::move(m_parent->m_current);
832  this->operator++();
833  return ret;
834  }
835 #pragma GCC diagnostic pop
836 
837 
838  reference operator*() const { return static_cast<reference>(*m_parent->m_current); }
839  // Why do we need static_cast<reference> instead of simply std::move ?
840  // See https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/iterator/move_iterator/operator*
841 
842  pointer operator->() const { return &*m_parent->m_current; }
843 
844  bool operator==(const iterator& other) const
845  {
846  return m_parent == other.m_parent;
847  }
848 
849  bool operator!=(const iterator& other) const
850  {
851  return m_parent != other.m_parent;
852  }
853 
854  private:
855 
856  friend seq;
857 
858  seq* m_parent;
859  };
860 
861  iterator begin() // NB: non-const, advances to the first element, (calls m_gen)
862  {
863  // An input-range is single-pass. Not expecting multiple calls to begin()
864  if(m_started && !m_resumable) {
865  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("seq::begin() can only be called once per instance. Set resumable(true) to override.");
866  }
867 
868  auto it = iterator{ m_ended ? nullptr : this };
869 
870  if(!m_started && !m_ended) {
871  m_started = true; // advance to the first element (or end)
872  ++it;
873  }
874  return it;
875  }
876 
877  static iterator end()
878  {
879  return {};
880  }
881 
882 #if 0
883  // not providing this because begin() may be once-callable
884 
885  bool empty() // nb: non-const because begin() is non-const.
886  { // should this be made const (make fields mutable) ?
887  //return m_ended; // can't do that - may be empty, but m_Advanced==fase
888  return begin() == end();
889  }
890 #endif
891 
892  /// By default, calling begin() a second time will throw, because
893  /// the default expectation is that begin() will restart from the beginning,
894  /// which does not hold with seq, or any input-range for that matter.
895  /// This may be suppressed with .resumable(true),
896  /// making it explicit that the user-code is aware that begin() will resume
897  /// from the current state.
898  seq& set_resumable(bool res = true)
899  {
900  m_resumable = res;
901  }
902 
903  Gen& get_gen()
904  {
905  return m_gen;
906  }
907 
908  const Gen& get_gen() const
909  {
910  return m_gen;
911  }
912 
913  operator std::vector<value_type>() && // rvalue-specific because after conversion
914  { // the seq will be consumed (m_ended)
915  assert(!m_ended);
916  //assert(!m_started); allow or prohibit?
917 
918  std::vector<value_type> ret{};
919 
920  if(m_current) {
921  ret.push_back(std::move(*m_current));
922  m_current.reset();
923  }
924 
925  for(auto x = m_gen(); x; x = m_gen()) {
926  ret.push_back(std::move(*x));
927  }
928 
929  m_started = true;
930  m_ended = true;
931 
932  return ret;
933  }
934 
935 
936  private:
937  friend class iterator;
938 
939  // so that we can access private fields in constructor taking seq<OtherGen>
940  template<typename U>
941  friend class seq;
942 
943  impl::maybe<value_type> m_current = {};
944  // Last value returned by m_gen.
945  // Can't be simply T because T
946  // might not be default-constructible.
947 
948  Gen m_gen; // nullary generator
949  bool m_started = false; // false iff did not advance to begin()
950  bool m_ended = false;
951  bool m_resumable = false; // if true, do not throw if called begin() more than once.
952  };
953 
954  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
955  template<typename Iterable>
956  struct refs_gen
957  {
958  Iterable& cont; // maybe const
959 
960  using value_type = decltype(std::ref(*cont.begin()));
961  // std::reference_wrapper< maybe-const Iterable::value_type>
962 
963  decltype(cont.begin()) it; // may be iterator or const_iterator
964 
965  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
966  {
967  if(it == cont.end()) {
968  return { };
969  } else {
970  return { *it++ };
971  }
972  }
973  };
974 
975 } // namespace impl
976 
977  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
978  /// @brief Adapt a generator function as `InputRange`.
979  /*!
980  @code
981  int i = 0;
982  int sum =
983  fn::seq([&i]
984  {
985  return i < 5 ? x++ : fn::end_seq();
986  })
987 
988  % fn::where([](int x)
989  {
990  return x > 2;
991  }) // 3, 4
992 
993  % fn::transform([](int x)
994  {
995  return x + 1;
996  }) // 4, 5
997 
998  % fn::foldl_d([](int out, int in)
999  {
1000  return out * 10 + in;
1001  });
1002 
1003  VERIFY(sum == 45);
1004  @endcode
1005  */
1006  template<typename NullaryInvokable>
1007  impl::seq<impl::catch_end<NullaryInvokable>> seq(NullaryInvokable gen_fn)
1008  {
1009  static_assert(!std::is_reference<decltype(gen_fn())>::value, "The type returned by gen_fn must be a value-type.");
1010  static_assert(!std::is_same<decltype(gen_fn()), void>::value, "You forgot a return-statement in your gen-function.");
1011  return { { std::move(gen_fn), false } };
1012  }
1013 
1014  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1015  /// @brief Adapt a reference to `Iterable` as `seq` yielding reference-wrappers.
1016  template<typename Iterable>
1017  impl::seq<impl::refs_gen<Iterable>> refs(Iterable& src)
1018  {
1019  // Prevent usage with input-ranges, since reference-wrappers will become dangling
1020  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::forward_iterator_tag>(src);
1021 
1022  return { { src, src.begin() } };
1023  }
1024 
1025  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1026  /// @brief Type-erase a `seq`.
1027  ///
1028  /// `any_seq_t` is implicitly constructible from any `seq`,
1029  /// wrapping the underlying `NullaryInvokable` as `std::function`.
1030  ///
1031  /// This may be useful when you want to declare a function or a method
1032  /// returning a seq, but don't want to define it with all the gory details
1033  /// in the header.
1034  ///
1035  /// NB: wrappnig a callable in a `std::function` is subject to
1036  /// performance-related considerations.
1037  /*!
1038  @code
1039  fn::any_seq_t<int> myseq =
1040  fn::seq([i = 0]() mutable
1041  {
1042  return i < 10 ? i++ : fn::end_seq();
1043  })
1044  % fn::where([](int x)
1045  {
1046  return x % 2 == 0;
1047  });
1048  @endcode
1049  */
1050  template<typename T>
1051  using any_seq_t = impl::seq<std::function<impl::maybe<T>()>>;
1052  /// @}
1053 
1054 
1055 namespace impl
1056 {
1057  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1058  // User-provided key_fn may be returning a std::reference_wrapper<...>.
1059  // So we'll be comparing keys using lt or eq, equipped to deal with that.
1060  // See also https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9139748/using-stdreference-wrapper-as-the-key-in-a-stdmap
1061 
1062  struct lt
1063  {
1064 
1065  template<typename T>
1066  bool operator()(const T& a, const T& b) const
1067  {
1068  return std::less<T>{}(a, b);
1069  }
1070 
1071  template<typename T>
1072  bool operator()(const std::reference_wrapper<T>& a,
1073  const std::reference_wrapper<T>& b) const
1074  {
1075  return std::less<T>{}(a.get(), b.get());
1076  }
1077  };
1078 
1079  struct eq
1080  {
1081  template<typename T>
1082  bool operator()(const T& a, const T& b) const
1083  {
1084  return a == b;
1085  }
1086 
1087  template<typename T>
1088  bool operator()(const std::reference_wrapper<T>& a,
1089  const std::reference_wrapper<T>& b) const
1090  {
1091  return a.get() == b.get();
1092  }
1093  };
1094 
1095  template<typename T>
1096  int compare(const T& a, const T&b)
1097  {
1098  return ( lt{}(a, b) ? -1
1099  : lt{}(b, a) ? 1
1100  : 0);
1101  }
1102 
1103 
1104  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1105  // @brief Value-wrapper with reversed operator<, used with by::decreasing
1106  template<typename T>
1107  struct gt
1108  {
1109  T val; // this has to be non-const, otherwise does not compile with T=bool (or int, etc)
1110  // when used as part of a tuple (e.g. in the big example
1111  // make_tuple(fn::by::decreasing(is_nc), ...); // compilation error if const T val; here
1112  // make_tuple(!is_nc, ...); // ok
1113  //
1114  // Having a const field also prevents the use of move-constructor
1115  // when passing by move.
1116 
1117  bool operator<(const gt& other) const
1118  {
1119  return other.val < this->val;
1120  }
1121 
1122  // operator== in case it will be used with group_adjacent_by or unique_adjacent_by
1123  bool operator==(const gt& other) const
1124  {
1125  return other.val == this->val;
1126  }
1127  };
1128 
1129  // composition of gt over key_fn
1130  template<typename F>
1131  struct gt_fn
1132  {
1133  const F key_fn;
1134 
1135  template<typename Arg>
1136  auto operator()(const Arg& arg) const -> gt<decltype(key_fn(arg))>
1137  {
1138  return { key_fn(arg) };
1139  }
1140  };
1141 
1142  // binary comparator composed over key_fn
1143  template<typename F>
1144  struct comp
1145  {
1146  const F key_fn;
1147 
1148  // NB: may be type-assymetric
1149  template<typename A, typename B>
1150  bool operator()(const A& a, const B& b) const
1151  {
1152  return lt{}(key_fn(a), key_fn(b));
1153  }
1154  };
1155 
1156 } // namespace impl
1157 
1158 
1159 /// @brief Common key-functions to use with sort_by/unque_by/group_all_by
1160 /// @code
1161 /// ptrs = %= fn::sort_by(fn::by::dereferenced{});
1162 /// std::move(pairs) % fn::group_all_by(fn::by::second{});
1163 /// @endcode
1164 namespace by
1165 {
1166  // sort() / unique() are simply sort_by<identity> and unique_adjacent_by<identity>
1167  struct identity
1168  {
1169  template<typename T>
1170  auto operator()(const T& x) const -> const T&
1171  {
1172  return x;
1173  }
1174  };
1175 
1176  struct dereferenced
1177  {
1178  template<typename P> // any dereferenceable type
1179  auto operator()(const P& ptr) const -> decltype(*ptr)
1180  {
1181  return *ptr;
1182  }
1183  };
1184 
1185  struct first
1186  {
1187  template<typename T>
1188  auto operator()(const T& x) const -> decltype(*&x.first) // *& so that decltype computes a reference
1189  {
1190  return x.first;
1191  }
1192  };
1193 
1194  struct second
1195  {
1196  template<typename T>
1197  auto operator()(const T& x) const -> decltype(*&x.second)
1198  {
1199  return x.second;
1200  }
1201  };
1202 
1203  /// e.g. for tuples or pairs, `fn::group_adjacent_by(fn::by::get<string>{})`
1204  template<typename U>
1205  struct get
1206  {
1207  template<typename T>
1208  auto operator()(const T& x) const -> const U&
1209  {
1210  return std::get<U>(x);
1211  }
1212  };
1213 
1214  /// @brief Wraps the passed value and exposes inverted operator<.
1215  /*!
1216  @code
1217  {{
1218  // sort by longest-first, then lexicographically
1219 
1220  const auto inp = std::vector<std::string>{ "2", "333", "1", "222", "3" };
1221  const auto expected = std::vector<std::string>{ "222", "333", "1", "2", "3" };
1222 
1223 
1224  auto ret1 = inp % fn::sort_by([](const string& s)
1225  {
1226  return std::make_tuple(fn::by::decreasing(s.size()), std::ref(s));
1227  });
1228  VERIFY(ret1 == expected);
1229 
1230 
1231  auto ret2 = inp % fn::sort_by([](const string& s)
1232  {
1233  return std::make_tuple(s.size(), fn::by::decreasing(std::ref(s)));
1234  }) % fn::reverse();
1235  VERIFY(ret2 == expected);
1236 
1237 
1238  // we can also compose by::decreasing with a key-function
1239  auto ret3 = inp % fn::sort_by(fn::by::flipped([](const std::string& s)
1240  {
1241  return std::make_tuple(s.size(), fn::by::decreasing(std::ref(s)));
1242  }));
1243  VERIFY(ret3 == expected);
1244 
1245 
1246  // we can also create a comparator from a key-function.
1247  auto ret4 = inp;
1248  gfx::timsort(ret4.begin(), ret4.end(), fn::by::make_comp([](const std::string& s)
1249  {
1250  return std::make_tuple(fn::by::decreasing(s.size()), std::ref(s));
1251  }));
1252  VERIFY(ret4 == expected);
1253 
1254 
1255  // NB: we can't use std::tie because fn::by::decreasing returns an rvalue,
1256  // so we use std::make_tuple and capture s by std::ref.
1257  }}
1258  @endcode
1259  */
1260  template<typename T>
1261  impl::gt<T> decreasing(T x)
1262  {
1263  // Note: we could perfect-forward T instead of taking it by value,
1264  // such that return type is gt<const reference>,
1265  // but this would allow misuse such as
1266  // fn::sorty_by([](const auto& x)
1267  // {
1268  // const auto key = x.get_key();
1269  // return fn::by::decreasing(key);
1270  // // if key is captured by reference,
1271  // // it becomes dangling after return.
1272  // });
1273  // Instead, will allow the user to explicitly
1274  // capture by-reference via reference-wrapper below.
1275 
1276  return { std::move(x) };
1277  }
1278 
1279  template<typename T>
1280  impl::gt<const T&> decreasing(std::reference_wrapper<T> x)
1281  {
1282  // unwrapping reference_wrapper and capturing by const-reference,
1283  // because otherwise unwrapped reference_wrapper won't bind to
1284  // operator< in gt::operator<.
1285  return { x.get() };
1286  }
1287 
1288  /// @brief Compose key_fn with `by::decreasing`.
1289  template<typename F>
1290  impl::gt_fn<F> flipped(F key_fn)
1291  {
1292  return { std::move(key_fn) };
1293  }
1294 
1295  /// @brief Make binary comparison predicate from a key-function
1296  template<typename F>
1297  impl::comp<F> make_comp(F key_fn)
1298  {
1299  return { std::move(key_fn) };
1300  }
1301 } // namespace by

1303 /// Common transform-functions that can be used as param to fn::transform
1304 namespace get

1306  struct dereferenced
1307  {

1309  auto operator()(P ptr) const -> typename std::remove_reference<decltype(std::move(*ptr))>::type
1310  {
1311  return std::move(*ptr);
1312  }
1313  };

1315  struct first
1316  {
1317  template<typename T>

1319  {

1321  }
1322  };

1324  struct second
1325  {
1326  template<typename T>
1327  auto operator()(T x) const -> typename T::second_type
1328  {

1330  }
1331  };

1333  struct enumerated
1334  {
1335  size_t i = 0UL;
1336 
1337  template<typename T>

1339  {

1345  /// @defgroup view Views
1346  /// @{
1347 
1348  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1349  /// @brief A view is just a pair of interators with begin() and end() interface.
1350  template<typename Iterator>
1351  class view
1352  {
1353  private:
1354  Iterator it_beg;
1355  Iterator it_end;
1356 
1357  public:
1358  view(Iterator b, Iterator e)
1359  : it_beg( std::move(b) )
1360  , it_end( std::move(e) )
1361  {}
1362 
1363  view() = default;
1364 
1365  using iterator = Iterator;
1366  using value_type = typename iterator::value_type;
1367 
1368  Iterator begin() const { return it_beg; }
1369  Iterator end() const { return it_end; }
1370 
1371  /// Truncate the view.
1372  ///
1373  /// Precondition: `b == begin() || e = end()`; throws `std::logic_error` otherwise.
1374  /// This does not affect the underlying range.
1375  void erase(Iterator b, Iterator e)
1376  {
1377  // We support the erase method to obviate view-specific overloads
1378  // for some hofs, e.g. take_while, take_first, drop_whille, drop_last, etc -
1379  // the container-specific overloads will work for views as well.
1380 
1381  if(b == it_beg) {
1382  // erase at front
1383  it_beg = e;
1384  } else if(e == it_end) {
1385 
1386  // erase at end
1387  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::forward_iterator_tag>(*this);
1388 
1389  it_end = b;
1390  } else {
1391  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Can only erase at the head or at the tail of the view");
1392  }
1393  }
1394 
1395  void clear()
1396  {
1397  it_beg = it_end;
1398  }
1399 
1400  bool empty() const
1401  {
1402  return it_beg == it_end;
1403  }
1404  };
1405 
1406  // Note: we named the methods from, such that usage like
1407  // auto sorted_vec = fn::from(it_beg, it_end) % fn::sort();
1408  // communicates that the range will be moved-from.
1409 
1410  /// @brief Create a range-view from a pair of iterators.
1411  template<typename Iterator>
1412  constexpr view<Iterator> from(Iterator it_beg, Iterator it_end) noexcept
1413  {
1414  return { std::move(it_beg), std::move(it_end) };
1415  }
1416 
1417  /// To enable composability of APIs returning a pair of iterators, e.g. std::equal_range
1418  template<typename Iterator>
1419  constexpr view<Iterator> from(std::pair<Iterator, Iterator> p) noexcept
1420  {
1421  return { std::move(p.first), std::move(p.second) };
1422  }
1423 
1424  /// Create a range-view for a container, or an iterable that has `begin` and `end` as free functions rather than methods.
1425  template<typename Iterable,
1426  typename Iterator = typename Iterable::iterator>
1427  constexpr view<Iterator> from(Iterable& src) noexcept
1428  {
1429  using std::begin;
1430  using std::end;
1431  return { begin(src), end(src) };
1432  }
1433 
1434  template<typename Iterable,
1435  typename Iterator = typename Iterable::const_iterator>
1436  constexpr view<Iterator> from(const Iterable& src) noexcept
1437  {
1438  // need a separate overload for const, because without it
1439  // begin(src) yields const_iterator that is not convertible
1440  // to normal iterator that's in the signature.
1441 
1442  using std::begin; // cbegin/cend here instead?
1443  using std::end;
1444  return { begin(src), end(src) };
1445  }
1446 
1447 
1448  template<typename Iterable,
1449  typename Iterator = typename Iterable::const_iterator>
1450  constexpr view<Iterator> cfrom(const Iterable& src) noexcept
1451  {
1452  using std::begin;
1453  using std::end;
1454  return { begin(src), end(src) };
1455  }
1456 
1457  /// @}
1458

1460 
1461 /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1462 /// @brief Implementations for corresponding static functions in fn::
1463 namespace impl
1464 {
1465  // Wrap an Iterable as gen-callable, yielding elements by move.
1466  struct to_seq
1467  {
1468  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1469  // We compose seqs by yanking m_gen from the input seq,
1470  // wrapping it into a nullary callable (see gen) that will do the
1471  // additional work (e.g. filter, transform, etc) and wrapping back as seq.
1472  // I.e. we're doing the monadic "burrito" technique.
1473  // See RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ
1474  //
1475  // The alternative is to wrap any range with adapting seq, but
1476  // this results in a to_seq at every layer instead of the outermost one.
1477  //
1478  // So if we want to work with a user-provided input-range or a container lazily,
1479  // we first need to wrap it as seq that will yield elements by-move.
1480  template<typename Iterable>
1481  struct gen
1482  {
1483  using value_type = typename Iterable::value_type;
1484  using iterator = typename Iterable::iterator;
1485 
1486  Iterable src_range;
1487  iterator it;
1488  bool started;
1489 
1490  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
1491  {
1492  if(!started) {
1493  started = true;
1494  it = src_range.begin();
1495  // r might not be a container (i.e. some input-range
1496  // and begin() may be non-const, so deferring until
1497  // the first call to operator() rather than
1498  // initializing it{ r.begin() } in constructor.
1499  } else if(it == src_range.end()) {
1500  ; // may be equal to end in case of repeated calls to operator() after ended
1501  } else {
1502  ++it;
1503  }
1504 
1505  if(it == src_range.end()) {
1506  return { };
1507  } else {
1508  return { std::move(*it) };
1509  }
1510  }
1511  };
1512 
1513  // pass-through if already a seq
1514  template<typename Gen>
1515  seq<Gen> operator()(seq<Gen> seq) const
1516  {
1517  return seq;
1518  }
1519 
1520  /// @brief Wrap a range (e.g. a container or a view) as seq.
1521  template<typename Iterable>
1522  seq<gen<Iterable>> operator()(Iterable src) const
1523  {
1524  return { { std::move(src) , {}, false } };
1525  }
1526  };
1527 
1528 
1529  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1530  struct to_vector
1531  {
1532  // passthrough overload
1533  template<typename T>
1534  std::vector<T> operator()(std::vector<T> vec) const
1535  {
1536  return vec;
1537  }
1538 
1539  // overload for a seq - invoke rvalue-specific implicit conversion
1540  template<typename Gen,
1541  typename Vec = std::vector<typename seq<Gen>::value_type>>
1542  Vec operator()(seq<Gen> r) const
1543  {
1544  return static_cast<Vec>(std::move(r));
1545  }
1546 
1547  // overload for other iterable: move-insert elements into vec
1548  template<typename Iterable,
1549  typename Vec = std::vector<typename Iterable::value_type> >
1550  Vec operator()(Iterable src) const
1551  {
1552  // Note: this will not compile with std::set
1553  // in conjunction with move-only value_type because
1554  // set's iterators are const, and std::move will try
1555  // and fail to use the copy-constructor.
1556 
1557  return this->operator()( Vec{
1558  std::make_move_iterator(src.begin()),
1559  std::make_move_iterator(src.end()) });
1560  }
1561 
1562  // an overload for map that will return a vector of
1563  // std::vector<std::pair<Key, Value>>> rather than
1564  // std::vector<std::pair<const Key, Value>>>, which is map's
1565  // value_type.
1566  // We want to remove the const because otherwise the vector's
1567  // functionality is crippled because the value-type is not
1568  // move-assigneable, so we can't do anything useful with it.
1569  //
1570  // TODO: generalize this for sets and arbitrary associative containers,
1571  // pre- and post- c++17.
1572  template<typename Key,
1573  typename Value,
1574  typename Vec = std::vector<std::pair<Key, Value>>>
1575  Vec operator()(std::map<Key, Value> m) const
1576  {
1577  Vec v{};
1578  v.reserve(m.size());
1579 
1580 #if __cplusplus >= 201703L
1581  while(!m.empty()) {
1582  auto h = m.extract(m.begin());
1583  v.emplace_back(std::move(h.key()),
1584  std::move(h.mapped()));
1585  }
1586 #else
1587  for(auto it = m.begin(), it_end = m.end();
1588  it != it_end;
1589  it = m.erase(it))
1590  {
1591  v.emplace_back(std::move(it->first), // this makes a copy due to const key
1592  std::move(it->second));
1593  }
1594 #endif
1595  return v;
1596  }
1597  };

1600  template<typename Container>

1611  std::make_move_iterator(src.begin()),
1612  std::make_move_iterator(src.end()));
1613 #else

1615  dest.insert(dest.end(), std::move(x));

1617 #endif

1638  struct exists_where
1639  {
1640  const Pred pred;
1641  bool ret;
1642

1644  exists_where operator!() &&
1645  {
1646  // don't want to make operator! non-const for lvalues,
1647  // so instead making it rvalue-specific to prevent
1648  // any misuse.
1649 
1650  ret = !ret;
1651  return std::move(*this);

1656  {

1658  if(pred(x))
1659  return ret;
1660  return !ret;

1664  // NB[3]: In for_each, foldl, foldl_d, foldl_1 we don't really need
1665  // the overloads for seq, because seq is Iterable, but by providing
1666  // them we work with underlying gens directly, bypassing the iterator
1667  // machinery layer of seq, potentially allowing the compiler to do
1668  // better job with optimization.
1669 
1670  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1671  template<typename F>
1672  struct for_each
1673  {
1674  F fn;
1675 
1676  template<typename Iterable>
1677  void operator()(Iterable&& src) const
1678  {
1679  for(auto it = src.begin(); it != src.end(); ++it) {
1680  fn(*it);
1681  }
1682 
1683  // Used to return by perfect-forwarding, i.e.
1684  // return-type = Iterable&&, and return std::forward<Iterable>(src);
1685  //
1686  // The intent was to allow downstream stages
1687  // after for_each. However,
1688  // 1) If Iterable is a single-pass seq,
1689  // it's not usable after the loop (will cause runtime error
1690  // if we try to iterate over it again).
1691  // 2) -Weffc++ says "should return by value" when
1692  // Iterable is passed by rvalue.
1693  //
1694  // So instead, will treat for_each as lfold-into-void.
1695  }
1696 
1697 
1698  // See NB[3]
1699  template<typename Gen>
1700  void operator()(seq<Gen> src) const
1701  {
1702  for(auto x = src.get_gen()(); x; x = src.get_gen()()) {
1703  fn(std::move(*x));
1704  impl::recycle(src.get_gen(), *x, impl::resolve_overload{});
1705  }
1706  }
1707  };
1708 
1709  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1710  template<typename Ret, typename Op>
1711  struct foldl
1712  {
1713  Ret init;
1714  Op fold_op;
1715 
1716  template<typename Iterable>
1717  Ret operator()(Iterable&& src) && // rvalue-specific because init will be moved-from
1718  { // (we have to, because Ret may be move-only)
1719 
1720  static_assert(std::is_same<Ret, decltype(fold_op(std::move(init), *src.begin()))>::value,
1721  "Type of Init must be the same as the return-type of F");
1722 
1723  for(auto it = src.begin(); it != src.end(); ++it) {
1724  init = fold_op(std::move(init), *it);
1725  }
1726 
1727  // NB: can't use std::accumulate because it does not do the std::move(init)
1728  // internally until c++20, so it won't compile with move-only types,
1729  // and will make copies for copyable types.
1730 
1731  return std::move(init);
1732  }
1733 
1734  // See NB[3]
1735  template<typename Gen>
1736  Ret operator()(seq<Gen> src) &&
1737  {
1738  for(auto x = src.get_gen()(); x; x = src.get_gen()()) {
1739  init = fold_op(std::move(init), std::move(*x));
1740  impl::recycle(src.get_gen(), *x, impl::resolve_overload{});
1741  }
1742  return std::move(init);
1743  }
1744  };

1746  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1747  template<typename Op>
1748  struct foldl_d
1749  {
1750  Op fold_op;
1751 
1752  struct any
1753  {
1754  template<typename T>
1755  operator T() const;
1756  };
1757 
1758  template<typename Iterable>
1759  auto operator()(Iterable&& src) const -> decltype(fold_op(any(), *src.begin()))
1760  {
1761  using ret_t = decltype(fold_op(any(), *src.begin()));
1762  auto ret = ret_t{};
1763 
1764  for(auto it = src.begin(); it != src.end(); ++it) {
1765  ret = fold_op(std::move(ret), *it);
1766  }
1767 
1768  return ret;
1769  }
1770 
1771 
1772  // See NB[3]
1773  template<typename Gen>
1774  auto operator()(seq<Gen> src) const -> decltype(fold_op(any(), std::move(*src.get_gen()())))
1775  {
1776  using ret_t = decltype(fold_op(any(), std::move(*src.get_gen()())));
1777  auto ret = ret_t{};
1778 
1779  for(auto x = src.get_gen()(); x; x = src.get_gen()()) {
1780  ret = fold_op(std::move(ret), std::move(*x));
1781  impl::recycle(src.get_gen(), *x, impl::resolve_overload{});
1782  }
1783 
1784  return ret;
1785  }
1786  };

1788  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1789  template<typename F>
1790  struct foldl_1
1791  {
1792  F fold_op;
1793 
1794  template<typename Iterable>
1795  auto operator()(Iterable&& src) const -> decltype(fold_op(std::move(*src.begin()), *src.begin()))
1796  {
1797  auto it = src.begin();
1798  auto it_end = src.end();
1799 
1800  if(it == it_end) {
1801  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Expected nonempty.");
1802  }
1803 
1804  auto init = *it;
1805 
1806  for(++it; it != it_end; ++it) {
1807  init = fold_op(std::move(init), *it);
1808  }
1809 
1810  return init;
1811  }
1812 
1813  // See NB[3]
1814  template<typename Gen>
1815  auto operator()(seq<Gen> src) const -> decltype(fold_op(std::move(*src.get_gen()()), std::move(*src.get_gen()())))
1816  {
1817  auto x1 = src.get_gen()();
1818 
1819  if(!x1) {
1820  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Expected nonempty.");
1821  }
1822 
1823  auto init = std::move(*x1);
1824 
1825  for(auto x = src.get_gen()(); x; x = src.get_gen()()) {
1826  init = fold_op(std::move(init), std::move(*x));
1827  }
1828 
1829  return init;
1830  }
1831  };

1833  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1834 
1835  // define operator() overload composing an input-seq
1836  // (gen in OutGen presumed to go first)
1837  // Basically, we unwrap the input seq, yanking its gen,
1838  // compose our gen over it, and wrap it back into seq.
1839 #define RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ(...) \
1840  template<typename InGen> \
1841  auto operator()(seq<InGen> in) const -> seq<gen<InGen>> \
1842  { \
1843  return { { std::move(in.get_gen()), __VA_ARGS__ } }; \
1844  }
1845 
1846  // Default implementation of operator() for cases where
1847  // there's no eager logic for Container-arg, and
1848  // we want to treat it the same as seq (overload above)
1849  // so we wrap Cont as to_seq::gen and do same as above.
1850  //
1851 #define RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_CONT(...) \
1852  template<typename Cont> \
1853  auto operator()(Cont cont) const -> seq<gen<to_seq::gen<Cont>>> \
1854  { \
1855  return { { { std::move(cont), { }, false }, __VA_ARGS__ } }; \
1856  } \
1857  // ^^^^^^^^^^
1858  // NB: it would be better, of course, to specify that `{ }` and `false`
1859  // as defaults in declarations of to_seq::gen fields instead of specifying them here,
1860  // but GCC-4.9.3 has problems with aggregate initialization in a presence
1861  // of field-defaults.
1862 
1863 
1864 #define RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_VIEW(...) \
1865  template<typename Iterator> \
1866  auto operator()(view<Iterator> v) const \
1867  -> seq<gen<to_seq::gen<view<Iterator>>>> \
1868  { \
1869  return { { { std::move(v), { }, false }, __VA_ARGS__ } }; \
1870  }
1871 
1872  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1873  template<typename F>
1874  struct transform
1875  {
1876  F map_fn;
1877 
1878  template<typename InGen>
1879  struct gen
1880  {
1881  InGen gen;
1882  F map_fn;
1883 
1884  using value_type = decltype(map_fn(std::move(*gen())));
1885 
1886  static_assert(!std::is_same<value_type, void>::value, "You forgot a return-statement in your transform-function.");
1887 
1888  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
1889  {
1890  // NB: passing map_fn as ref, as it may be stateful (e.g. counting)
1891  //return gen().transform(std::ref(map_fn));
1892 
1893  auto x = gen();
1894  if(!x) {
1895  return { };
1896  }
1897 
1898  auto ret = map_fn(std::move(*x));
1899  impl::recycle(gen, *x, impl::resolve_overload{});
1900  return std::move(ret); // I'd expect copy elision here, but
1901  // GCC4.9.3 tries to use copy-constructor here
1902  }
1903  };
1904 
1905  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( map_fn )
1906  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_CONT( map_fn )
1907  // Given a container, we return a lazy seq rather than
1908  // transforming all elements eagerly, because inputs may be
1909  // "small", while outputs may be "large" in terms of
1910  // memory and/or computation, so we want to defer it.
1911  };

1914  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1915  struct sliding_window
1916  {
1917  const size_t win_size;
1918 
1919  template<typename Iterable>
1920  struct gen_c
1921  {
1922  using iterator = typename Iterable::iterator;
1923  using value_type = view<iterator>;
1924 
1925  Iterable cont;
1926  iterator win_beg;
1927  iterator win_end;
1928  bool started;
1929  const size_t win_size;
1930 
1931  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
1932  {
1933  if(!started) {
1934  started = true;
1935 
1936  win_beg = cont.begin();
1937  win_end = cont.begin();
1938 
1939  // advance view's it_end by win_size
1940  size_t n = 0;
1941  for(size_t i = 0; i < win_size && win_end != cont.end(); ++i) {
1942  ++win_end;
1943  ++n;
1944  }
1945 
1946  if(n < win_size) {
1947  return { };
1948  } else {
1949  return value_type{ win_beg, win_end };
1950  }
1951  }
1952 
1953  if(win_end == cont.end()) {
1954  return { };
1955  }
1956 
1957  ++win_beg;
1958  ++win_end;
1959 
1960  return { { win_beg, win_end } };
1961  }
1962  };
1963 
1964  template<typename Iterable>
1965  auto operator()(Iterable inps) const -> seq<gen_c<Iterable>>
1966  {
1967  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::forward_iterator_tag>(inps);
1968 
1969  return { { std::move(inps),
1970  {}, {}, // iteratos
1971  false, // started
1972  win_size } };
1973  }
1974 
1975  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
1976 
1977  // for seq: buffer win_size elements in a queue
1978  template<typename InGen>
1979  struct gen
1980  {
1981  InGen gen;
1982 
1983  using inp_t = typename InGen::value_type;
1984  using queue_t = std::deque<inp_t>;
1985  using value_type = view<typename queue_t::iterator>;
1986 
1987  queue_t queue;
1988  value_type curr;
1989  const size_t win_size;
1990 
1991  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
1992  {
1993  if(!queue.empty()) {
1994  queue.pop_front();
1995  }
1996 
1997  while(queue.size() < win_size) {
1998  auto x = gen();
1999  if(!x) {
2000  return { };
2001  }
2002  queue.push_back(std::move(*x));
2003  }
2004 
2005  return { { queue.begin(), queue.end() } };
2006  }
2007  };
2008 
2009  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( {}, {{}, {}}, win_size )
2010  };

2019  {
2020  return std::async(std::launch::async, std::move(gen));
2021  }

2024  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2025  template<typename F, typename Async>
2026  struct par_transform
2027  {
2028  const Async async;
2029  const F map_fn; // const, because expecting this to be thread-safe
2030  size_t queue_cap; // 0 means in-this-thread.
2031 
2032  par_transform& queue_capacity(size_t cap)
2033  {
2034  queue_cap = cap;
2035  return *this;
2036  }
2037 
2038  template<typename InGen>
2039  struct gen
2040  {
2041  InGen gen;
2042  const Async async;
2043  const F map_fn;
2044  const size_t queue_cap;
2045 
2046  // TODO: with some handwaving may be able to use std::vector
2047  using fmapped_t = decltype(map_fn(std::move(*gen())));
2048  using value_type = fmapped_t;
2049  using queue_t = std::deque<std::future<fmapped_t>>;
2050 
2051  queue_t queue;
2052 
2053  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
2054  {
2055  // behave like a plain impl::transform in in-this-thread mode
2056  if(queue_cap == 0) {
2057  assert(queue.empty());
2058  auto x = gen();
2059  if(!x) {
2060  return { };
2061  } else {
2062  return map_fn(std::move(*x));
2063  }
2064  }
2065 
2066  struct job_t // wrapper for passing inp to fn by-move
2067  {
2068  using input_t = typename InGen::value_type;
2069 
2070  const F& fn;
2071  input_t inp;
2072 
2073  auto operator()() -> decltype(fn(std::move(inp)))
2074  {
2075  return fn(std::move(inp));
2076  }
2077  };
2078 
2079  // if have more inputs, top-off the queue with async-tasks.
2080  while(queue.size() < queue_cap) {
2081  auto x = gen();
2082 
2083  if(!x) {
2084  break;
2085  }
2086 
2087  queue.emplace_back(
2088  async(
2089  job_t{ map_fn, std::move(*x) }));
2090  }
2091 
2092  if(queue.empty()) {
2093  return { };
2094  }
2095 
2096  auto ret = queue.front().get(); // this returns by-value
2097  queue.pop_front();
2098  return { ret };
2099  }
2100  };
2101 
2102  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( async, map_fn, queue_cap, {} )
2103  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_CONT( async, map_fn, queue_cap, {} )
2104  };
2105 #endif

2116  struct gen
2117  {

2119  F fn; // unary user-function taking the generator (NOT the result)
2120

2137  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2138  // The implementation below was added to enable the user-code (fn)
2139  // interrogate the passed gen whether it can yield another value
2140  // (so the user-code can wrap-up without throwing), so it prefetches
2141  // the next value from in_gen, and the gen-wrapper conversion to
2142  // bool is false iff the prefetched maybe<...> is empty.
2143  //
2144  // The alternative is to have gen return a maybe<...>,
2145  // but we want to isolate the user-code from
2146  // implementation details.
2147  template<typename F>
2148  struct adapt
2149  {
2150  F fn;
2151 
2152  template<typename InGen>
2153  struct gen
2154  {
2155  InGen in_gen; // upstream nullary generator
2156  F fn; // unary user-function taking the generator (NOT the result)
2157 
2158  using inp_t = typename InGen::value_type;
2159 
2160  maybe<inp_t> inp;
2161  bool started;
2162 
2163  // the gen-wrapper that will be passed to fn
2164  struct gen_wr
2165  {
2166  gen* parent;
2167 
2168  auto operator()() -> inp_t
2169  {
2170  assert(parent);
2171 
2172  if(!parent->inp) {
2173  // user-code called gen() too many times
2174  throw end_seq::exception{};
2175  }
2176 
2177  auto ret = std::move(*parent->inp);
2178  parent->next();
2179  return ret;
2180  }
2181 
2182  explicit operator bool() const
2183  {
2184  assert(parent);
2185 
2186  return bool(parent->inp);
2187  }
2188  };
2189 
2190  void next()
2191  {
2192  inp = in_gen();
2193  }
2194 
2195  using value_type = decltype(fn(gen_wr{ nullptr }));
2196 
2197  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
2198  {
2199  if(!started) {
2200  started = true;
2201  next();
2202  }
2203 
2204  // user-function fn may throw end-of-inputs,
2205  // either explicitly or by invoking gen after
2206  // its conversion to bool equals false. We
2207  // catch it here and return empty-maybe exactly
2208  // as we do in catch_end-wrapper.
2209  try {
2210  return { fn(gen_wr{ this }) };
2211 
2212  } catch( const end_seq::exception& ) {
2213  return { };
2214  }
2215  }
2216  };
2217 
2218  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( fn, {}, false )
2219  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_CONT( fn, {}, false )
2220  };
2221 
2222 #endif

2231  struct gen

2240  {

2265  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2266  struct take_last
2267  {
2268  const size_t cap;
2269 
2270  template<typename Gen>
2271  auto operator()(seq<Gen> r) const -> std::vector<typename seq<Gen>::value_type>
2272  {
2273  // consume all elements, keep last `cap` in the queue
2274  std::vector<typename seq<Gen>::value_type> queue;
2275 
2276  queue.reserve(cap);
2277 
2278  size_t i = 0; // count of insertions
2279 
2280  for(auto x = r.get_gen()(); x; x = r.get_gen()()) {
2281  if(i < cap) {
2282  // NB: can't call queue.resize() because that imposes
2283  // default-constructible on value_type, so instead
2284  // push_back in the beginning.
2285  queue.push_back(std::move(*x));
2286  } else {
2287  queue[i % cap] = std::move(*x);
2288  }
2289  ++i;
2290  }
2291 
2292  if(cap < i) {
2293  // put the contents in proper order.
2294  auto it = queue.begin();
2295  std::advance(it, i % cap); // oldest inserted element
2296  std::rotate(queue.begin(), it, queue.end());
2297  }
2298 
2299  return queue;
2300  }
2301 
2302  template<typename Iterable>
2303  Iterable operator()(Iterable&& inps) const
2304  {
2305  // Iterable may be a container or view
2306  static_assert(std::is_rvalue_reference<Iterable&&>::value, "");
2307 
2308  // in case cont is a view:
2309  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::forward_iterator_tag>(inps);
2310  const auto size = std::distance(inps.begin(), inps.end());
2311 
2312  if(decltype(size)(cap) < size) {
2313  auto it = inps.begin();
2314  std::advance(it, size - cap);
2315  inps.erase(inps.begin(), it);
2316  }
2317  return std::move(inps);
2318  }
2319 
2320  template<typename Cont>
2321  Cont operator()(const Cont& cont) const
2322  {
2323  Cont ret{};
2324 
2325  if(cap < cont.size()) {
2326  auto it = cont.begin();
2327  std::advance(it, cont.size() - cap);
2328  ret.insert(ret.end(), it, cont.end());
2329  }
2330  return ret;
2331  }
2332  };

2335  struct drop_last
2336  {
2337  const size_t n;
2338 
2339  template<typename InGen>
2340  struct gen
2341  {
2342  InGen gen;
2343  size_t cap;
2344 
2345  using value_type = typename InGen::value_type;
2346  using vec_t = std::vector<value_type>;
2347 
2348  vec_t queue;
2349  size_t i;
2350 
2351  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
2352  {
2353  if(queue.capacity() < cap) {
2354  queue.reserve(cap);
2355  }
2356 
2357  while(i < cap) {
2358  auto x = gen();
2359  if(!x) {
2360  return { };
2361  }
2362  queue.push_back(std::move(*x));
2363  ++i;
2364  }
2365 
2366  auto& dest = queue[i++ % cap];
2367  auto ret = std::move(dest);
2368  auto x = gen();
2369  if(!x) {
2370  return { };
2371  } else {
2372  dest = std::move(*x);
2373  return { std::move(ret) };
2374  }
2375  }
2376  };
2377

2384  static_assert(std::is_rvalue_reference<Iterable&&>::value, "");
2385 
2386  // in case cont is a view:
2387  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::forward_iterator_tag>(inps);
2388  const auto size = std::distance(inps.begin(), inps.end());
2389 
2390  if(decltype(size)(n) < size) {
2391  auto it = inps.begin();
2392  std::advance(it, size - n);
2393  inps.erase(it, inps.end());
2394  } else {
2395  inps.clear();
2396  }
2397 
2398  return std::move(inps);
2399  }

2406

2408  auto it = cont.begin();
2409  std::advance(it, cont.size() - n);
2410  ret.insert(ret.end(), cont.begin(), it);
2411  }
2412

2414  }

2469  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2470  template<typename Pred>
2471  struct where
2472  {
2473  Pred pred; // NB: may be mutable lambda, e.g.
2474  // where([i = 0]() mutable { return i++ < 10; }).
2475  //
2476  // In container-specific overloads will need to
2477  // make a copy and use that to be const-compliant.
2478 
2479  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2480  template<typename InGen>
2481  struct gen
2482  {
2483  InGen gen;
2484  Pred pred;
2485 
2486  using value_type = typename InGen::value_type;
2487 
2488  static_assert(std::is_same<decltype(pred(*gen())), bool>::value, "The return value of predicate must be convertible to bool.");
2489  // is_convertible<..., bool> would suffice, but if it's not bool there's
2490  // a good chance that the user code is inadvertently doing something
2491  // the programmer did not intend, so we'll be a little more stringent
2492  // to guard against this.
2493 
2494  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
2495  {
2496  auto x = gen();
2497  while(x && !pred(*x)) {
2498  x = gen();
2499  }
2500 
2501  return x;
2502  }
2503  };
2504 
2505  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( pred )
2506 
2507  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2508 
2509  // If cont is passed as const-reference,
2510  // make another container, copying only the
2511  // elements satisfying the predicate.
2512  template<typename Cont>
2513  Cont operator()(const Cont& cont) const
2514  {
2515  Cont ret{};
2516  auto pred_copy = pred;
2517  std::copy_if(cont.begin(),
2518  cont.end(),
2519  std::inserter(ret, ret.end()),
2520  pred_copy);
2521  return ret;
2522  }
2523 
2524  // Why the above overload won't bind to non-const-reference args,
2525  // necessitating this overload?
2526  template<typename Cont>
2527  Cont operator()(Cont& cont) const
2528  {
2529  const Cont& const_cont = cont;
2530  return this->operator()(const_cont);
2531  }
2532 
2533  // If cont is passed as rvalue-reference,
2534  // erase elements not satisfying predicate.
2535  // (this also supports the case of container
2536  // with move-only value-type).
2537  template<typename Cont>
2538  Cont operator()(Cont&& cont) const //-> typename std::enable_if<std::is_rvalue_reference<Cont&&>::value, Cont>::type
2539  {
2540  static_assert(std::is_rvalue_reference<Cont&&>::value, "");
2541 
2542  x_EraseFrom(cont, impl::resolve_overload{}); // SFINAE-dispatch to erase-remove or iterate-erase overload.
2543  return std::move(cont); // must move, because Cont may contain move-only elements
2544  // (e.g. won't compile otherwise with Cont=std::vector<std::unique_ptr<int>>)
2545  }
2546 
2547  private:
2548  template<typename Cont>
2549  void x_EraseRemove(Cont& cont) const
2550  {
2551  auto pred_copy = pred;
2552  cont.erase(
2553  std::remove_if(
2554  cont.begin(), cont.end(),
2555  [&pred_copy](const typename Cont::value_type& x)
2556  {
2557  return !pred_copy(x);
2558  }),
2559  cont.end());
2560 
2561  // Using std::not1(pred) instead of the lambda above won't compile:
2562  // error: no type named 'argument_type'...
2563  }
2564 
2565 
2566  // High-priority overload for containers where can call remove_if.
2567  template<typename Cont>
2568  auto x_EraseFrom(Cont& cont, pr_high) const -> decltype(void(cont.front()))
2569  {
2570  // This overload must be made unpalatable to SFINAE unless
2571  // std::remove_if is viable for Cont, e.g. feature-checking
2572  // as follows:
2573  //
2574  // A) Can call std::remove:
2575  // -> decltype(void( std::remove(cont.begin(), cont.end(), *cont.begin()) ))
2576  //
2577  // B) Or simplifying, iterator's reference_type is non-const (assignable),
2578  // -> decltype(void( *cont.begin() = std::move(*cont.begin()) ))
2579  // or -> decltype(std::swap(*cont.begin(), *cont.begin()))
2580  //
2581  // However, SFINAE still considers this overload viable for std::map
2582  // even though map's value_type is not move-assignable, (due to key being const);
2583  // i.e. the lines below should not and would not compile.
2584  //
2585  // std::remove(cont.begin(), cont.end(), *cont.begin());
2586  // *cont.begin() = std::move(*cont.begin());
2587  //
2588  // I'm not sure why SFINAE fails to reject it in the decltype,
2589  // resulting in ambiguous resolution of x_EraseFrom.
2590  //
2591  // Anyway, that's why we're instead feature-testing for SequenceContainer
2592  // based the presence of cont.front()
2593  // https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/named_req/SequenceContainer
2594  //
2595  // Update: This is no longer an issue with newer compilers, so this must have been
2596  // a compiler bug. However, Leaving the cont.front() check in place for now.
2597 
2598  x_EraseRemove(cont);
2599  }
2600 
2601  // for a view I can't tell which idiom to use in SFINAE
2602  // (e.g. is it a view into a map or into a vec?)
2603  // So will specialize for view and require random_access_iterator,
2604  // so we can be sure erase-remove is viable
2605  template<typename Iterator>
2606  void x_EraseFrom(view<Iterator>& v, pr_high) const
2607  {
2608  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::random_access_iterator_tag>(v);
2609  x_EraseRemove(v);
2610  }
2611 
2612  // Low-priority overload where remove_if is not viable, but
2613  // the container has equal_range method (e.g. set and associative
2614  // containers) so it is reasonable to expect that iterate-erase
2615  // idiom is applicable.
2616  template<typename Cont>
2617  auto x_EraseFrom(Cont& cont, pr_low) const
2618  -> decltype(void(
2619  cont.equal_range(
2620  std::declval<typename Cont::key_type const&>())))
2621  {
2622  auto pred_copy = pred;
2623  for(auto it = cont.begin(), it_end =cont.end();
2624  it != it_end;
2625  it = pred_copy(*it) ? std::next(it)
2626  : cont.erase(it))
2627  {
2628  ;
2629  }
2630  }
2631 
2632  template<typename NotACont>
2633  static void x_EraseFrom(NotACont&, pr_lowest)
2634  {
2635  static_assert(sizeof(NotACont) == 0, "The argument to fn::impl::where is expected to be either a seq<...> or a sequence container or an associative container having equal_range method.");
2636  TheTypeInQuestionIs<NotACont>{};
2637  }
2638  };

2641  template<typename SortedRange, typename F>
2642  struct in_sorted_by

2649  {

2654  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2655  template<typename F>
2656  struct where_max_by
2657  {
2658  const F key_fn;
2659  const int use_max; // 1 for max, -1 for use-min
2660 
2661  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2662  // Note: rather than returning a seq, as with where() or transform(),
2663  // we're returning a vector with accumulated results (we had to accumulate
2664  // the results somewhere, and there's no point in wrapping back in seq.
2665  template<typename InGen,
2666  typename Ret = typename std::vector<typename seq<InGen>::value_type> >
2667  auto operator()(seq<InGen> in) const -> Ret
2668  {
2669  Ret ret{};
2670 
2671  auto& gen = in.get_gen();
2672 
2673  for(auto x = gen(); x; x = gen()) {
2674 
2675  const auto which = ret.empty() ? 0
2676  : impl::compare(key_fn(ret.front()),
2677  key_fn(*x)) * use_max;
2678  if(which < 0) {
2679  ret.clear();
2680  ret.push_back(std::move(*x));
2681 
2682  } else if(which > 0) {
2683  ;
2684  } else {
2685  ret.push_back(std::move(*x));
2686  }
2687  }
2688 
2689  if(ret.capacity() >= ret.size() * 2) {
2690  ret.shrink_to_fit();
2691  }
2692 
2693  return ret;
2694  }
2695 
2696 
2697 
2698  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2699  template<typename Cont,
2700  typename Ret = std::vector<typename Cont::value_type> >
2701  Ret operator()(Cont cont) const
2702  {
2703  // TODO: Take Cont as forwarding reference instead of by value
2704  // such that if it is passed by lvalue-reference we don't need to
2705  // copy all elements; will only copy the maximal ones.
2706  // (copy or move value from the iterator depending on whether
2707  // cont is lvalue or rvalue-reference?)
2708 
2709  // NB[2]: if we're taking lvalue of key_fn(element),
2710  // be mindful that key may contain references to keyed object.
2711  // (hopefully const, but we can't even assume that).
2712  // (e.g. make_tuple(....) unwraps reference-wrappers and returns
2713  // a tuple that may contain references.
2714  //
2715  // Therefore:
2716  // 1) we can't reassign keys, e.g. best_key = max(best_key, current_key),
2717  // as this will assign the internal reference (if non-const)
2718  // or will not compile (if reference is const).
2719  //
2720  // 2) The value of key may become invalidated if referenced
2721  // element is assigned or moved from (explicitly, or under the hood,
2722  // e.g. while reallocating when a std::vector is resized in push_back,
2723  // or when the element is moved to a different position by erase-remove
2724  // algorithm.
2725 
2726  // NB: we could reuse the same logic for both input and Cont use-cases,
2727  // but having multi-pass capability with Cont allows us to do less
2728  // memory churn (we only need to move elements-of-interest into ret).
2729 
2730  Ret ret{};
2731 
2732  if(cont.empty())
2733  return ret;
2734 
2735  auto first_best_it = cont.begin();
2736  auto last_best_it = cont.begin();
2737  size_t n = 1; // count of max-elements
2738 
2739  {
2740  auto it = cont.begin();
2741  for(++it; it != cont.end(); ++it) {
2742  const int which = impl::compare(key_fn(*it),
2743  key_fn(*first_best_it)) * use_max;
2744  if(which < 0) {
2745  ; // not-best
2746  } else if(which > 0) {
2747  // new-best
2748  first_best_it = last_best_it = it;
2749  n = 1;
2750  } else {
2751  last_best_it = it;
2752  n++;
2753  }
2754  }
2755  }
2756 
2757  ret.reserve(n);
2758  ret.push_back(std::move(*first_best_it));
2759  ++first_best_it;
2760  ++last_best_it; // convert to end
2761 
2762  for(auto it = first_best_it; it != last_best_it; ++it)
2763  if(impl::compare(key_fn(*it),
2764  key_fn(ret.back())) * use_max >= 0)
2765  {
2766  ret.push_back(std::move(*it));
2767  }
2768 
2769  return ret;
2770 
2771 #if 0 // An example of what NOT to do:
2772  auto best_key = key_fn(*cont.begin());
2773  for(const auto& e : cont) {
2774  auto key = key_fn(e);
2775  if(impl::compare(best_key, key)*use_max > 0) {
2776  best_key = std::move(key); // BUG: modifies referenced object via
2777  // internal non-const references in key.
2778  // (or will not compile if references are const)
2779  }
2780 
2781  return fn::where(
2782  [&, this](const typename Ret::value_type& x)
2783  {
2784  return impl::compare(key_fn(x), best_key)*use_max >= 0;
2785  })(std::forward<Cont>(cont));
2786  // BUG: best_key may contain a reference, which is invalidated mid-processing
2787  // when best-element is moved inside erase-remove loop in fn::where.
2788 #endif
2789  }
2790  };
2791

2860  // NB: sort and reverse have identical signatures for overloads
2861 
2862  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2863  // I made a decision to deviate from STL naming convention,
2864  // where std::sort is unstable, and made fn::sort/sort_by a stable-sort.
2865  //
2866  // I think STL should have followed the principle of least astonishment and made
2867  // std::sort a stable-sort, and have an additonal std::unstable_sort version.
2868  // (STL is known for its poor names that tend to surprise novice programmers).
2869  // That is, by default sort should do "the most right" thing,
2870  // and have an differently named (e.g. "unstable_sort") optimizing
2871  // version that can make additional assumptions about the inputs.
2872  //
2873  // In real-life sort_by/group_all_by/unique_all_by use-cases we don't
2874  // simply sort ints or strings where unstable-sort would do; rather,
2875  // we sort some objects by some subset of properties, where the sort-key only
2876  // partially differentiates between the objects, and a two objects
2877  // that are equivalent according to the sort key don't necessarily
2878  // compare equal, and so we shouldn't be swapping their relative order.
2879  template<typename F>
2880  struct sort_by
2881  {
2882  const F key_fn;
2883 
2884  template<typename Gen>
2885  auto operator()(seq<Gen> r) const -> std::vector<typename seq<Gen>::value_type>
2886  {
2887  return this->operator()(to_vector{}(std::move(r)));
2888  }
2889 
2890  template<typename Iterable>
2891  Iterable operator()(Iterable src) const
2892  {
2893  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::random_access_iterator_tag>(src);
2894 
2895  // this will fire if Iterable is std::map, where value_type is std::pair<const Key, Value>,
2896  // which is not move-assignable because of constness.
2897  static_assert(std::is_move_assignable<typename Iterable::value_type>::value, "value_type must be move-assignable.");
2898  auto op_less = [this](const typename Iterable::value_type& x,
2899  const typename Iterable::value_type& y)
2900  {
2901  return lt{}(key_fn(x), key_fn(y));
2902  };
2903 
2904  std::stable_sort(src.begin(), src.end(), op_less); // [compilation-error-hint]: expecting sortable container; try fn::to_vector() first.
2905  return src;
2906  }
2907  };
2908 
2909  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2910 
2911  // NB: initially thought of having stable_sort_by and unstable_sort_by versions,
2912  // and for unstable_sort_by/Cont use std::sort, and for unstable_sort_by/seq<..>
2913  // seq use lazy heap sort. The unstable-ness, however, is different between the two.
2914  // So instead decided to go with lazy_sort_by for both Cont and seq<>
2915 
2916  // Initially dump all elements and heapify in O(n);
2917  // lazily yield elements with pop_heap in O(log(n))
2918  //
2919  // TODO: can we make this stable? E.g. falling-back on pointer comparison (probably not)
2920  // or keeping a vector of std::pair<decltype(gen()), size_t> where ::second is the
2921  // original ordinal.
2922  template<typename F>
2923  struct lazy_sort_by
2924  {
2925  const F key_fn;
2926 
2927  template<typename InGen>
2928  struct gen
2929  {
2930  InGen gen;
2931  const F key_fn;
2932 
2933  using value_type = typename InGen::value_type;
2934  using vec_t = std::vector<value_type>;
2935 
2936  static_assert(std::is_move_assignable<value_type>::value, "value_type must be move-assignable.");
2937 
2938  vec_t heap;
2939  bool heapified;
2940 
2941  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
2942  {
2943  auto op_gt = [this](const value_type& x,
2944  const value_type& y)
2945  {
2946  return lt{}(key_fn(y), key_fn(x));
2947  };
2948 
2949  if(!heapified) {
2950  assert(heap.empty());
2951  heapified = true;
2952 
2953  // TODO: if gen is to_gen wrapper, move elements
2954  // directly from the underlying Iterable.
2955  for(auto x = gen(); x; x = gen()) {
2956  heap.push_back(std::move(*x));
2957  }
2958 
2959  std::make_heap(heap.begin(), heap.end(), op_gt);
2960  }
2961 
2962  if(heap.empty()) {
2963  return { };
2964  }
2965 
2966  std::pop_heap(heap.begin(), heap.end(), op_gt);
2967  auto ret = std::move(heap.back());
2968  heap.pop_back();
2969  return { std::move(ret) };
2970  }
2971  };
2972 
2973  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( key_fn, {}, false )
2974  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_CONT( key_fn, {}, false )
2975  };
2976 
2977  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
2978  template<typename F>
2979  struct take_top_n_by
2980  {
2981  const F key_fn;
2982  const size_t cap;
2983 
2984  template<typename Iterable>
2985  auto operator()(Iterable src) const -> std::vector<typename Iterable::value_type>
2986  {
2987  // TODO: if Iterable is a vector, do partial-sort, decreasing, take_first(n), and reverse.
2988  //
2989  // Take by forwarding-reference here instead of by-value?
2990  // (Same question as in where_max_by)
2991 
2992  using value_type = typename Iterable::value_type;
2993 
2994  // this will fire if Iterable is std::map, where value_type is std::pair<const Key, Value>,
2995  // which is not move-assignable because of constness.
2996  static_assert(std::is_move_assignable<value_type>::value, "value_type must be move-assignable.");
2997 
2998  auto op_gt = [this](const value_type& x,
2999  const value_type& y)
3000  {
3001  return lt{}(key_fn(y), key_fn(x));
3002  };
3003 
3004  // NB: can't use priority_queue, because it provides
3005  // const-only exposition of elements, so we can't use
3006  // it with move-only types.
3007 
3008  std::vector<value_type> heap{}; // min-heap, (min at front)
3009  heap.reserve(cap);
3010 
3011  if(cap > 0)
3012  for(auto&& x : src)
3013  {
3014  const bool insert =
3015  heap.size() < cap
3016  || [&]
3017  {
3018  const auto& key_x = key_fn(x); // NB: temporary lifetime extension
3019  const auto& key_h = key_fn(heap.front());
3020 
3021  // key_fn is expected to be "light", but in case it's not negligibly light
3022  // we factor-out evaluation of key_fn here, because we can.
3023 
3024  return lt{}(key_x, key_h) ? false // worse than current-min
3025  : lt{}(key_h, key_x) ? true // better than current-min
3026  : false; // equiv to current-min (we're at capacity, so keeping current min)
3027  }();
3028 
3029  if(!insert) {
3030  continue;
3031  }
3032 
3033  if(heap.size() >= cap) {
3034  std::pop_heap(heap.begin(), heap.end(), op_gt);
3035  heap.pop_back();
3036  }
3037 
3038  heap.push_back(std::move(x));
3039  std::push_heap(heap.begin(), heap.end(), op_gt);
3040  }
3041 
3042  std::sort_heap(heap.begin(), heap.end(), op_gt);
3043  std::reverse(heap.begin(), heap.end());
3044 
3045  return heap;
3046  }
3047  };
