3049  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3050  template<typename F, typename BinaryPred = impl::eq>
3051  struct group_adjacent_by
3052  {
3053  // We parametrize to both key_fn and pred2 to reuse
3054  // this for both
3055  // group_adjacent_by: key_fn:user-provided, pred2=impl::eq
3056  // group_adjacent_if: key_fn=impl::by::identity, pred2:user-provided.
3057 
3058  const F key_fn;
3059  const BinaryPred pred2;
3060 
3061 #if 1
3062  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3063  // A simple version that accumulates equivalent-group in a vector,
3064  // and yield vector_t. This makes it easy to deal-with (no seq-of
3065  // seqs), but it needs to allocate a return std::vector per-group.
3066  // (Edit: unless the use-case supports recycling (see below))
3067  template<typename InGen>
3068  struct gen
3069  {
3070  InGen gen;
3071  const F key_fn;
3072  const BinaryPred pred2;
3073 
3074  using inp_t = typename InGen::value_type;
3075 
3076  using value_type = typename std::conditional<
3077  std::is_same<inp_t, char>::value,
3078  std::string,
3079  std::vector<inp_t> >::type;
3080 
3081  static_assert(std::is_move_assignable<value_type>::value, "value_type must be move-assignable.");
3082 
3083 
3084  value_type next;
3085  value_type garbage;
3086 
3087  // instead of allocating a new vector, the caller, prior to calling
3088  // the operator(), may choose to disown existing vector so we can
3089  // reuse its internal storage
3090 
3091  void recycle(value_type& grbg)
3092  {
3093  garbage = std::move(grbg);
3094  }
3095 
3096  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
3097  {
3098  // NB: number of calls to key_fn shall be max(0, 2*(n-1))
3099  // (as required by fn::chunker)
3100 
3101  auto curr = std::move(next);
3102  next = std::move(garbage);
3103  next.clear(); // clearing does not deallocate internal storage
3104 
3105  for(auto x = gen(); x; x = gen()) {
3106  if(curr.empty() || pred2(key_fn(curr.back()), key_fn(*x))) {
3107  curr.push_back(std::move(*x));
3108  } else {
3109  next.push_back(std::move(*x));
3110  break;
3111  }
3112  }
3113 
3114  if(curr.empty()) {
3115  return { };
3116  }
3117 
3118  return std::move(curr);
3119  }
3120  };
3121 
3122  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( key_fn, pred2, {}, {} )
3123 
3124  // view may be an InputRange, so treat as seq.
3125  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_VIEW( key_fn, pred2, {}, {} )
3126 #else
3127  // Experimental implementation returning non-allocating
3128  // seq-of-subseqs instead of seq-of-vectors.
3129  //
3130  // After trying it out in various use-cases,
3131  // decided against it, because while elegant in theory,
3132  // it is not very useful and finnicky in practice
3133  // due to subrange single-passness (think of it as if
3134  // an element of a collection could only be accessed
3135  // once), so nearly every time this necessitates a
3136  // conversion to vector to be able to do "real work"
3137  // (e.g. to reorder subranges).
3138  //
3139  // Also:
3140  //
3141  // * Subranges depend on the lifetime of the parent.
3142  //
3143  // * Subranges must be consumed entirely and in order.
3144  //
3145  // * Not straightforward conversion to vector-of-vectors
3146  // (can't simply convert to vector-of-subseqs, because see above).
3147  // Calculation of type requires some recursive metafunction handwaving and recursive implicit conversions.
3148 
3149 
3150  [ implementation deleted ]
3151 
3152  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( key_fn, {} )
3153 #endif
3154 
3155  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3156  template<typename Cont>
3157  auto operator()(Cont cont) const -> std::vector<Cont>
3158  {
3159  // NB: number of calls to key_fn shall be max(0, 2*(n-1))
3160  // (see chunker)
3161 
3162  std::vector<Cont> ret;
3163 
3164  auto it = cont.begin();
3165  const auto it_end = cont.end();
3166 
3167  if(it == it_end) {
3168  return ret;
3169  }
3170 
3171  ret.push_back(Cont{});
3172  ret.back().insert(ret.back().end(), std::move(*it)); // [compilation-error-hint]: Expecting Cont's value-type to be end-insertable container.
3173  ++it;
3174 
3175  for(; it != it_end; ++it) {
3176  if(!pred2(key_fn(*ret.back().crbegin()), // NB: last!
3177  key_fn(*it)))
3178  {
3179  ret.push_back(Cont{});
3180  }
3181  auto& dest = ret.back();
3182  dest.insert(dest.end(), std::move(*it));
3183  }
3184 
3185  return ret;
3186  }
3187  };

3190  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3191  // used for in_groups_of(n)
3192  struct chunker
3193  {
3194  const size_t chunk_size;
3195  mutable size_t n_calls;
3196 
3197  template<typename T>
3198  size_t operator()(const T&) const
3199  {
3200  // chunker is called with group_adjacent_by.
3201  // If we had one call to key_fn per element,
3202  // we could chunk in groups of 10 like
3203  // elems % fn::group_adjacent_by([n = 0UL](const auto){ return n++/10; });
3204  //
3205  // in group_adjacent_by we call the key_fn 2*(n-1) times.
3206  return ++n_calls/2/chunk_size;
3207  }
3208  };

3312  struct concat

3315  struct gen
3316  {

3318 
3319  using gen_value_t = typename InGen::value_type;
3320  using group_t = maybe<gen_value_t>;
3321  // via maybe, because might not be default-constructible;
3322  // or could be a seq<...>, holding a closure under the hood,
3323  // rendering the seq not move-assigneable.
3324

3326  using value_type = typename gen_value_t::value_type;

3329  iterator it;
3330 
3331 #if 0 // We don't really need this
3332 
3333  // -Weffc++ recommends explicit assignment operator because

3347  current_group = gen();
3348 
3349  if(!current_group) {
3350  return { };
3351  }
3352 
3353  it = (*current_group).begin();
3354  }
3355 
3356  //postfix++ may not be available
3357  value_type ret = std::move(*it);
3358  ++it;
3359  return { std::move(ret) };
3360  }
3361  };

3418

3424  next.reset();

3428  curr = std::move(x);
3429  } else if( impl::eq{}(key_fn(*curr), key_fn(*x))) {
3430  continue; // skip equivalent elements
3431  } else {
3432  next = std::move(x);
3433  break;
3434  }
3435  }
3436

3438  }

3453  {

3455  }),

3465  template<typename F>
3466  struct unique_all_by
3467  {
3468  const F key_fn;
3469 
3470 #if 1
3471  /*
3472  Experimental lazy implementation for seq: keep a map of keys of seen elements
3473  and skip if seen. We need to guard against the keys becoming dangling
3474  while in the map, e.g. if key_fn returns a type that is a reference, refence-wrapper,
3475  or a value-type containing these (e.g. a tuple).
3476 
3477  Can check against this by requiring the key-type to be default-constructible
3478  (references, reference-wrappers, tuples-containing-references, etc. will not be).
3479  Is this sufficient?
3480  */
3481 
3482  template<typename InGen>
3483  struct gen
3484  {
3485  InGen gen;
3486  const F key_fn; // lifetime of returned key shall be independent of arg.
3487 
3488  using value_type = typename InGen::value_type;
3489 
3490  using key_t = typename std::decay<decltype(key_fn(*gen()))>::type;
3491  // key_fn normally yields a const-reference, but we'll be storing
3492  // keys in a map, so need to decay the type (remove_cvref would do).
3493 
3494  static_assert(std::is_default_constructible<key_t>::value, "The type returned by key_fn in unique_all_by must be default-constructible and have the lifetime independent of arg.");
3495  // In case key_fn returns a reference-wrapper or a tie-tuple containing
3496  // a reference, these will become invalidated as keys in the map
3497  // when the referenced object goes out of scope, so we guard against
3498  // these by requiring default-constructible on key_t.
3499 
3500  using seen_t = std::map<key_t, bool>;
3501  // might as well have used std::set, but to #include fewer things will
3502  // repurpose std::map that's already included for other things.
3503 
3504  seen_t seen;
3505 
3506  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
3507  {
3508  auto x = gen();
3509 
3510  if(!x) {
3511  return { };
3512  }
3513  auto k = key_fn(*x);
3514 
3515  while(!seen.emplace(std::move(k), true).second) {
3516  x = gen();
3517  if(!x) {
3518  break;
3519  }
3520  k = key_fn(*x);
3521  }
3522  return x;
3523  }
3524  };
3525 
3526  RANGELESS_FN_OVERLOAD_FOR_SEQ( key_fn, {} )
3527 #endif

3532  unique_adjacent_by<F>{ key_fn }(
3533  to_vector{}(
3534  std::move(src))))

3544  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3545  // Concat a pair of (possibly heterogeous) `Iterables`.
3546  template<typename Iterable2>
3547  struct append
3548  {
3549  Iterable2 src2;
3550 
3551  template<typename Iterable1>
3552  struct gen
3553  {
3554  Iterable1 inps1;
3555  Iterable2 inps2;
3556  typename Iterable1::iterator it1;
3557  typename Iterable2::iterator it2;
3558  int which; // 0: not-started;
3559  // 1: in range1
3560  // 2: in range2
3561  using value_type =
3562  typename std::common_type<
3563  typename Iterable1::value_type,
3564  typename Iterable2::value_type
3565  >::type;
3566 
3567  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
3568  {
3569  return which == 1 && it1 != inps1.end() ? std::move(*it1++)
3570  : which == 2 && it2 != inps2.end() ? std::move(*it2++)
3571  : which == 0 ? (which = 1, it1 = inps1.begin(), (*this)())
3572  : which == 1 ? (which = 2, it2 = inps2.begin(), (*this)())
3573  : maybe<value_type>{ };
3574  }
3575  };
3576 
3577  template<typename Iterable1>
3578  auto operator()(Iterable1 src1) && -> seq<gen<Iterable1>> // rvalue-specific because src2 is moved-from
3579  {
3580  return { { std::move(src1), std::move(src2), {}, {}, 0 } };
3581  }
3582  };

3584  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3585  template<typename Iterable2, typename BinaryFn>
3586  struct zip_with
3587  {
3588  Iterable2 src2;
3589  BinaryFn fn;
3590 
3591  template<typename Iterable1>
3592  struct gen
3593  {
3594  BinaryFn fn;
3595  Iterable1 src1;
3596  Iterable2 src2;
3597  typename Iterable1::iterator it1;
3598  typename Iterable2::iterator it2;
3599  bool started;
3600 
3601  using value_type = decltype(fn(std::move(*it1),
3602  std::move(*it2)));
3603 
3604  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
3605  {
3606  if(!started) {
3607  it1 = src1.begin();
3608  it2 = src2.begin();
3609  started = true;
3610  }
3611 
3612  if(it1 == src1.end() || it2 == src2.end()) {
3613  return { };
3614  }
3615 
3616  auto ret = fn(std::move(*it1), std::move(*it2));
3617  ++it1;
3618  ++it2;
3619  return { std::move(ret) };
3620  }
3621  };
3622 
3623  template<typename Iterable1>
3624  auto operator()(Iterable1 src1) && -> seq<gen<Iterable1>> // rvalue-specific because src2 is moved-from
3625  {
3626  return { { std::move(fn), std::move(src1), std::move(src2), {}, {}, false } };
3627  }
3628  };

3630  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3631  template<typename BinaryFn>
3632  struct zip_adjacent
3633  {
3634  BinaryFn fn;
3635 
3636  template<typename Iterable>
3637  struct gen
3638  {
3639  BinaryFn fn;
3640  Iterable src;
3641  typename Iterable::iterator it;
3642  bool started;
3643 
3644  using value_type = decltype(fn(*it, *it));
3645 
3646  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
3647  {
3648  if(!started) {
3649  it = src.begin();
3650  started = true;
3651  }
3652 
3653  auto prev_it = it == src.end() ? it : it++;
3654 
3655  if(it != src.end()) {
3656  return { fn(*prev_it, *it) };
3657  } else {
3658  return { };
3659  }
3660  }
3661  };
3662 
3663  template<typename Iterable>
3664  auto operator()(Iterable src) && -> seq<gen<Iterable>>
3665  {
3666  impl::require_iterator_category_at_least<std::forward_iterator_tag>(src);
3667  return { { std::move(fn), std::move(src), {}, false } };
3668  }
3669  };

3671  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3672  template<typename Iterable2, typename BinaryFn>
3673  struct cartesian_product_with
3674  {
3675  Iterable2 src2;
3676  BinaryFn fn;
3677 
3678  template<typename Iterable1>
3679  struct gen
3680  {
3681  BinaryFn fn;
3682  Iterable1 src1;
3683  Iterable2 src2;
3684  typename Iterable1::iterator it1;
3685  typename Iterable2::iterator it2;
3686  bool started;
3687 
3688  // Checking against input-range semantics.
3689  // Checking against moving iterators (yielding rvalue-references)
3690  // because if fn takes a param by value and the iterator yields
3691  // it will be moved-from.
3692  static_assert(!std::is_rvalue_reference<decltype(*--it1)>::value, "For cartesian-product expecting upstream iterable to be a bidirectional range yielding lvalue-references or values");
3693  static_assert(!std::is_rvalue_reference<decltype(*--it2)>::value, "For cartesian-product expecting parameter-iterable to be a bidirectional range yielding lvalue-references or values");
3694 
3695  using value_type = decltype(fn(*it1, *it2));
3696 
3697  auto operator()() -> maybe<value_type>
3698  {
3699  if(!started) {
3700  it1 = src1.begin();
3701  it2 = src2.begin();
3702  started = true;
3703  if(it1 == src1.end() || it2 == src2.end()) {
3704  return { };
3705  }
3706  }
3707 
3708  while(it2 == src2.end()) {
3709  it2 = src2.begin();
3710 
3711  ++it1;
3712  if(it1 == src1.end()) {
3713  return { };
3714  }
3715  }
3716 
3717  auto ret = fn(*it1, *it2);
3718  ++it2;
3719  return { std::move(ret) };
3720  }
3721  };
3722 
3723  template<typename Iterable1>
3724  auto operator()(Iterable1 src1) && -> seq<gen<Iterable1>> // rvalue-specific because range2 is moved-from
3725  {
3726  return { { std::move(fn), std::move(src1), std::move(src2), {}, {}, false } };
3727  }
3728  };

3731 
3732  struct memoizer_detail
3733  {
3734  template<class Ret, class Arg>
3735  struct lambda_traits_detail
3736  {
3737  using ret = Ret;
3738  using arg = Arg;
3739  };
3740 
3741  template<class L>
3742  struct lambda_traits
3743  : lambda_traits<decltype(&L::operator())>
3744  {};
3745 
3746  // NB: not providing non-const version (must be pure)
3747  template<class Ret, class Class, class Arg>
3748  struct lambda_traits<Ret(Class::*)(Arg) const>
3749  : lambda_traits_detail<Ret, Arg>
3750  {};
3751  };
3752 
3753  template<typename F>
3754  struct memoizer
3755  {
3756  using traits = impl::memoizer_detail::lambda_traits<F>;
3757  using Arg = typename std::remove_reference<typename traits::arg>::type;
3758  using Ret = typename traits::ret; // NB: can be const and/or reference
3759  using Cache = std::map<Arg, Ret>;
3760 
3761  F fn;
3762  mutable Cache m; // mutable, because operator() must be const
3763  // e.g. we may be memoizing some key_fn, and
3764  // those are expected to be const
3765 
3766  const Ret& operator()(const Arg& arg) const
3767  {
3768  auto it = m.find(arg);
3769  return it != m.end() ? it->second
3770  : m.emplace(arg, fn(arg)).first->second;
3771  }
3772  };

3774  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
3775  template<typename F>
3776  struct scope_guard
3777  {
3778  F fn;
3779  bool dismissed;
3780 
3781  void dismiss()
3782  {
3783  dismissed = true;
3784  }
3785 
3786  ~scope_guard() noexcept(noexcept(fn()))
3787  {
3788  if(!dismissed)
3789  fn(); // NB: it's up to m_fn to decide whether to catch exceptions.
3790  }
3791  };

3802  inline impl::to_vector to_vector()
3803  {
3804  return {};
3805  }

3807  /// @brief Wrap an `Iterable`, taken by value, as `seq` yielding elements by-move.
3808  ///
3809  /// This is a dual of `to_vector`. It can be used to adapt your own `InputRange` as
3810  /// `seq`, but it can also be used to wrap a container to force lazy evaluation
3811  /// e.g. `std::move(container) % fn::to_seq() % fn::group_adjacent_by(key_fn) % fn::take_first()`
3812  inline impl::to_seq to_seq()
3813  {
3814  return {};
3815  }
3816 
3817  /// e.g. `auto set_of_ints = fn::seq(...) % ... % fn::to(std::set<int>{})`;
3818  template<typename Container>
3819  impl::to<Container> to(Container dest)
3820  {

3831  /// @}
3832  /// @defgroup transform Transform and Adapt
3833  ///
3834  /// @{
3835 
3836  /// @brief Create a custom processing-stage function-object.
3837  ///
3838  /// This is somewhat similar to `fn::transform`, except the correspondence between
3839  /// inputs and outputs is not necessarily 1:1, and instead of taking a single element to transform
3840  /// we take a nullary generator callable `gen` and use it to fetch however many input elements
3841  /// we need to generate the next output element.
3842  ///
3843  /// NB: If `bool(gen)==false`, the next invocation of gen() shall throw `fn::end_seq::exception` signaling end-of-inputs.
3844  /*!
3845  @code
3846  auto my_transform = [](auto fn)
3847  {
3848  return fn::adapt([fn = std::move(fn)](auto gen)
3849  {
3850  return fn(gen());
3851  });
3852  };
3853 
3854  auto my_where = [](auto pred)
3855  {
3856  return fn::adapt([pred = std::move(pred)](auto gen)
3857  {
3858  auto x = gen();
3859  while(!pred(x)) {
3860  x = gen();
3861  }
3862  return x;
3863  });
3864  };
3865 
3866  auto my_take_while = [](auto pred)
3867  {
3868  return fn::adapt([pred = std::move(pred)](auto gen)
3869  {
3870  auto x = gen();
3871  return pred(x) ? std::move(x) : fn::end_seq();
3872  });
3873  };
3874 
3875  auto my_intersperse = [](auto delim)
3876  {
3877 #if 1
3878  return [delim = std::move(delim)](auto inputs)
3879  {
3880  return fn::seq([ delim,
3881  inputs = std::move(inputs),
3882  it = inputs.end(),
3883  started = false,
3884  flag = false]() mutable
3885  {
3886  if(!started) {
3887  started = true;
3888  it = inputs.begin();
3889  }
3890  return it == inputs.end() ? fn::end_seq()
3891  : (flag = !flag) ? std::move(*it++)
3892  : delim;
3893  });
3894  };
3895 
3896 #elif 0 // or
3897 
3898  return [delim = std::move(delim)](auto inputs)
3899  {
3900  return std::move(inputs)
3901  % fn::transform([delim](auto inp)
3902  {
3903  return std::array<decltype(inp), 2>{{ std::move(inp), delim }};
3904  })
3905  % fn::concat()
3906  % fn::drop_last(); // drop trailing delim
3907  };
3908 
3909 #else // or
3910 
3911  return fn::adapt([delim, flag = false](auto gen) mutable
3912  {
3913  return !gen ? fn::end_seq()
3914  : (flag = !flag) ? gen()
3915  : delim;
3916  });
3917 #endif
3918  };
3919 
3920 
3921  auto my_inclusive_scan = []
3922  {
3923  return fn::adapt([sum = 0](auto gen) mutable
3924  {
3925  return sum += gen();
3926  });
3927  };
3928 
3929  auto res =
3930  fn::seq([i = 0]() mutable
3931  {
3932  return i++;
3933  }) // 0,1,2,3,...
3934 
3935  % my_where([](int x)
3936  {
3937  return x >= 3;
3938  }) // 3,4,5,...
3939 
3940  % my_take_while([](int x)
3941  {
3942  return x <= 5;
3943  }) // 3,4,5
3944 
3945  % my_intersperse(-1) // 3,-1,4,-1,5
3946 
3947  % my_transform([](int x)
3948  {
3949  return x + 1;
3950  }) // 4,0,5,0,6
3951 
3952  % my_inclusive_scan() // 4,4,9,9,15
3953 
3954  % fn::to_vector();
3955 
3956  VERIFY((res == vec_t{{4, 4, 9, 9, 15}}));
3957  @endcode
3958 
3959  A more realistic example: suppose you have a pipeline
3960  transforming inputs to outputs in parallel, and you want to
3961  compress the output, but the outputs are small and compressing
3962  them individually would be ineffective, and you want to
3963  serialize the incoming results into a buffer of some minimum
3964  size, e.g. 100kb, before passing it to the compressing stage.
3965  @code
3966  auto make_result = [](std::string s){ return s; };
3967  auto compress_block = [](std::string s){ return s; };
3968  auto write_to_ostr = [](std::string s){ std::cout << s; };
3969 
3970  namespace fn = rangeless::fn;
3971  using fn::operators::operator%;
3972 
3973  fn::seq([&]() -> std::string
3974  {
3975  std::string line;
3976  return std::getline(std::cin, line) ? std::move(line)
3977  : fn::end_seq();
3978  })
3979 
3980  % fn::transform_in_parallel(make_result)
3981 
3982  % fn::adapt([](auto get_next)
3983  {
3984  std::ostringstream buf{};
3985 
3986  while(get_next && buf.tellp() < 100000) {
3987  buf << get_next();
3988  }
3989 
3990  return buf.tellp() ? buf.str() : fn::end_seq();
3991  })
3992 
3993  % fn::transform_in_parallel(compress_block)
3994 
3995  % fn::for_each(write_to_ostr);
3996 
3997  @endcode
3998  */
3999  template<typename F>
4000  impl::adapt<F> adapt(F fn)
4001  {
4002  return { std::move(fn) };
4003  }
4004 
4005  ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4006  /// @brief Create a `seq` yielding results of applying the transform functions to input-elements.
4007  ///
4008  /// Returns a unary function-object, which will capture the arg by value and
4009  /// return an adapted `seq<...>` which will yield results of invoking
4010  /// `map_fn` on the elements (passed by value) of arg.
4011  /// See `fn::where` for an example.
4012  template<typename F>
4013  impl::transform<F> transform(F map_fn)
4014  {
4015  // Rationale:
4016  // <br>
4017  // 1) A possible implementation for a container-input could assume that
4018  // `transform` function is inexpensive to recompute on-demand (this is
4019  // this approach in `range-v3` which may call `transform` multiple times
4020  // per element depending on the access pattern from the downstream views).
4021  //
4022  // 2) An implementation could require the result-type to be cacheable
4023  // and assume it is 'light' in terms of memory requirements and memoize the results.
4024  //
4025  // Our approach of applying `transform` lazily allows us to
4026  // make neither assumption and apply `transform` at most once per element and without caching.
4027  // The user-code may always follow that by fn::to_vector() when necessary.
4028 
4029  return { std::move(map_fn) };
4030  }
4031 
4032 #if 0
4033  // see comments around struct composed
4034  template<typename F, typename... Fs>
4035  auto transform(F fn, Fs... fns) -> impl::transform<decltype(impl::compose(std::move(fn), std::move(fns)...))>
4036  {
4037  return { impl::compose(std::move(fn), std::move(fns)...) };
4038  }
4039 #endif
4040 
4041 
4042 
4043 #if RANGELESS_FN_ENABLE_PARALLEL
4044 
4045 
4046  /// @brief Parallelized version of `fn::transform`
4047  ///
4048  /// Requires `#define RANGELESS_FN_ENABLE_PARALLEL 1` before `#include fn.hpp` because
4049  /// it brings in "heavy" STL `#include`s (`<future>` and `<thread>`).
4050  ///
4051  /// `queue_capacity` is the maximum number of simultaneosly-running `std::async`-tasks, each executing a single invocation of `map_fn`.
4052  ///
4053  /// NB: if the execution time of `map_fn` is highly variable, having higher capacity may help, such that
4054  /// tasks continue to execute while we're blocked waiting on a result from a long-running task.
4055  ///
4056  /// NB: If the tasks are too small compared to overhead of running as async-task,
4057  /// it may be helpful to batch them (see `fn::in_groups_of`), have `map_fn` produce
4058  /// a vector of outputs from a vector of inputs, and `fn::concat` the outputs.
4059  ///
4060  /// `map_fn` is required to be thread-safe.
4061  ///
4062  /// NB: the body of the `map_fn` would normally compute the result in-place,
4063  /// but it could also, for example, execute a subprocess do it, or offload it
4064  /// to a cloud or a compute-farm, etc.
4065  ///
4066  /// ---
4067  /// Q: Why do we need this? We have parallel `std::transform` and `std::transform_reduce` in c++17?
4068  ///
4069  /// A: Parallel `std::transform` requires a multi-pass `ForwardRange`
4070  /// rather than `InputRange`, and `std::terminate`s if any of the tasks throws.
4071  /// `std::transform_reduce` requires `ForwardRange` and type-symmetric, associative, and commutative `BinaryOp`
4072  /// (making it next-to-useless).
4073  ///
4074  /*!
4075  @code
4076  // Example: implement parallelized gzip compressor (a-la pigz)
4077 
4078  #define RANGELESS_FN_ENABLE_PARALLEL 1
4079  #include "fn.hpp"
4080 
4081  #include <util/compress/stream_util.hpp>
4082 
4083  int main()
4084  {
4085  auto& istr = std::cin;
4086  auto& ostr = std::cout;
4087 
4088  istr.exceptions(std::ios::badbit);
4089  ostr.exceptions(std::ios::failbit | std::ios::badbit);
4090 
4091  namespace fn = rangeless::fn;
4092  using fn::operators::operator%;
4093  using bytes_t = std::string;
4094 
4095  fn::seq([&istr]() -> bytes_t
4096  {
4097  auto buf = bytes_t(1000000UL, '\0');
4098  istr.read(&buf[0], std::streamsize(buf.size()));
4099  buf.resize(size_t(istr.gcount()));
4100  return !buf.empty() ? std::move(buf) : fn::end_seq();
4101  })
4102 
4103  % fn::transform_in_parallel([](bytes_t buf) -> bytes_t
4104  {
4105  // compress the block.
4106  std::ostringstream local_ostr;
4107  ncbi::CCompressOStream{
4108  local_ostr,
4109  ncbi::CCompressOStream::eGZipFile } << buf;
4110  return local_ostr.str();
4111 
4112  }).queue_capacity( std::thread::hardware_concurrency() )
4113 
4114  % fn::for_each([&ostr](bytes_t buf)
4115  {
4116  ostr.write(buf.data(), std::streamsize(buf.size()));
4117  });
4118 
4119  return istr.eof() && !istr.bad() ? 0 : 1;
4120  }
4121 
4122  @endcode
4123 
4124  See an similar examples using [RaftLib](https://medium.com/cat-dev-urandom/simplifying-parallel-applications-for-c-an-example-parallel-bzip2-using-raftlib-with-performance-f69cc8f7f962)
4125  or [TBB](https://software.intel.com/en-us/node/506068)
4126  */
4127  template<typename F>
4128  impl::par_transform<F, impl::std_async> transform_in_parallel(F map_fn)
4129  {
4130  return { impl::std_async{}, std::move(map_fn), std::thread::hardware_concurrency() };
4131  }
4132 
4133 
4134  /// @brief A version of `transform_in_parallel` that uses a user-provided Async (e.g. backed by a fancy work-stealing thread-pool implementation).
4135  ///
4136  /// `Async` is a unary invokable having the following signature:
4137  /// `template<typename NullaryInvokable> operator()(NullaryInvokable job) const -> std::future<decltype(job())>`
4138  ///
4139  /// NB: `Async` must be copy-constructible (may be passed via `std::ref` as appropriate).
4140  ///
4141  /// A single-thread pool can be used to offload the transform-stage to a separate thread if `transform` is not parallelizeable.
4142  /*!
4143  @code
4144  auto res2 =
4145  std::vector{{1,2,3,4,5}} // can be an InputRange
4146 
4147  % fn::transform_in_parallel([](auto x)
4148  {
4149  return std::to_string(x);
4150  },
4151  [&my_thread_pool](auto job) -> std::future<decltype(job())>
4152  {
4153  return my_thread_pool.enqueue(std::move(job));
4154  }).queue_capacity(10)
4155 
4156  % fn::foldl_d([](std::string out, std::string in)
4157  {
4158  return std::move(out) + "," + in;
4159  });
4160  VERIFY(res2 == ",1,2,3,4,5");
4161  @endcode
4162  */
4163  template<typename F, typename Async>
4164  impl::par_transform<F, Async> transform_in_parallel(F map_fn, Async async)
4165  {
4166  return { std::move(async), std::move(map_fn), std::thread::hardware_concurrency() };
4167  }
4168 #endif
4169 
4170  /// @}
4171  /// @defgroup folding Folds and Loops
4172  /// @{
4173 
4174  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4175  /*! @brief Range-based version of c++20 (copy-free) `std::accumulate`
4176  *
4177  * @see foldl_d
4178  * @see foldl_1
4179  @code
4180  using namespace fn::operators;
4181  const std::string x = vec_t{ 1, 2, 3 }
4182  % fn::foldl(std::string{"^"}, // init
4183  [](std::string out, int in) // fold-op
4184  {
4185  return std::move(out) + "|" + std::to_string(in);
4186  });
4187 
4188  VERIFY(x == "^|1|2|3");
4189  @endcode
4190 
4191  NB: The body of the fold-loop is `init = binary_op(std::move(init), *it);`
4192  If `it` is a `move`-ing iterator, like that of an `seq`,
4193  you'd take `in` by value or rvalue-reference in your binary operator,
4194  whereas if it's a regular iterator yielding lvalue-references, you'd
4195  take it by const or non-const reference.
4196  */
4197  template<typename Result, typename Op>
4198  impl::foldl<Result, Op> foldl(Result init, Op binary_op)
4199  {
4200  // NB: idiomatically the init value goes after the binary op,
4201  // but most of the time binary-op is a multiline lambda, and having
4202  // the init arg visually far-removed from the call-site
4203  // make things less readable, i.e. foldl([](...){ many lines }, init).
4204  // So placing the binary-op last.
4205  // (Tried it both ways, and found this order preferable).
4206 
4207  return { std::move(init), std::move(binary_op) };
4208  }
4209 
4210  /// Fold-Left-with-Default: this version uses default-initialized value for init.
4211  /*!
4212  * @see foldl
4213  * @see foldl_1
4214  @code
4215  const std::string x = vec_t{ 1, 2, 3 }
4216  % fn::foldl_d(
4217  [](std::string out, int in)
4218  {
4219  return std::move(out) + "|" + std::to_string(in);
4220  });
4221 
4222  VERIFY(x == "|1|2|3");
4223  @endcode
4224  */
4225  template<typename Op>
4226  impl::foldl_d<Op> foldl_d(Op binary_op)
4227  {
4228  return { std::move(binary_op) };
4229  }
4230 
4231  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4232  /// Init-free version of foldl (first element is used as init); requires at least one element.
4233  /*!
4234  * @see foldl
4235  * @see foldl_d
4236  *
4237  @code
4238  const auto min_int =
4239  std::vector<std::string>{{ "11", "-333", "22" }}
4240  % fn::transform([](const string& s) { return std::stoi(s); })
4241  % fn::foldl_1([](int out, int in) { return std::min(out, in); });
4242 
4243  VERIFY(min_int == -333);
4244  @endcode
4245  */
4246  template<typename Op>
4247  impl::foldl_1<Op> foldl_1(Op binary_op)

4335  /*!

4337  // 1) If arg is a container passed by lvalue-reference,
4338  // return a copy of the container with elements

4343  // remove the unsatisfying elements using erase-remove idiom and return the container.
4344  //
4345  // 2.2) If arg is a container having equal_range method (sets, associative containers, etc),
4346  // remove the unsatisfying elements using iterate-erase idiom and return the container.

4350  // yield elements satisfying the predicate:

4356  % fn::transform( [](int x) { return x + 1; }) // 4, 5
4357  % fn::foldl_d( [](int out, int in) { return out*10 + in; });

4359  @endcode

4363  {
4364  return { std::move(pred) };

4753  /// @{
4754 
4755  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4756  /*! @brief Access unique element matching the predicate.
4757  *
4758  * Throw unless found exactly one element matching the predicate.
4759  * Returns const or non-const reference depending on the constness of the container.
4760  * @see set_unique
4761  @code
4762  const CConstRef<CUser_object>& model_evidence_uo =
4763  fn::get_unique(seq_feat.GetExts(), [](CConstRef<CUser_object> uo)
4764  {
4765  return uo->GetType().GetStr() == "ModelEvidence";
4766  });
4767  @endcode
4768  */
4769  template<typename Container, typename P>
4770  auto get_unique(Container& container, P&& pred) -> decltype(*container.begin())
4771  {
4772  auto best_it = container.end();
4773  size_t n = 0;
4774 
4775  for(auto it = container.begin(),
4776  it_end = container.end();
4777 
4778  it != it_end; ++it)
4779  {
4780  if(pred(*it)) {
4781  best_it = it;
4782  ++n;
4783  }
4784  }
4785 
4786  if(n != 1) {
4787  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Expected unique element satisfying search criteria, found "
4788  + std::to_string(n) + ".");
4789  }
4790 
4791  return *best_it;
4792  }
4793 
4794  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4795  /// @brief Similar to get_unique, but end-insert an element if missing.
4796  ///
4797  /*!
4798  @code
4799  CRef<CSeqdesc>& gb_desc =
4800  fn::set_unique(seq_entry.SetDescr().Set(), [](CConstRef<CSeqdesc> d)
4801  {
4802  return d->IsGenbank();
4803  },
4804  [] // add if missing (must satisfy pred)
4805  {
4806  auto g = Ref(new CSeqdesc);
4807  g->SetGenbank();
4808  return g;
4809  });
4810  @endcode
4811  */
4812  template<typename Container, typename P, typename Construct>
4813  auto set_unique(Container& container, P&& pred, Construct&& con) -> decltype(*container.begin())
4814  {
4815  auto best_it = container.end();
4816  size_t n = 0;
4817 
4818  for(auto it = container.begin(),
4819  it_end = container.end();
4820 
4821  it != it_end; ++it)
4822  {
4823  if(pred(*it)) {
4824  best_it = it;
4825  ++n;
4826  }
4827  }
4828 
4829  if(n == 0) {
4830  best_it = container.insert(container.end(), con());
4831  ++n;
4832  if(!pred(*best_it)) {
4833  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("New element does not satisfy predicate.");
4834  }
4835  }
4836 
4837  if(n != 1) {
4838  RANGELESS_FN_THROW("Expected unique element satisfying search criteria, found "
4839  + std::to_string(n) + ".");
4840  }
4841 
4842  return *best_it;
4843  }

4846  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4847 
4848  /// e.g. `const CConstRef<CSeq_align> aln = first_or_default( get_alns_annot(...)->Get() );`
4849  template<typename Container>
4850  auto first_or_default(const Container& c) -> typename Container::value_type
4851  {
4852  return c.begin() == c.end() ? typename Container::value_type{} : *c.begin();
4853  }
4854 
4855  template<typename Container, typename Pred>
4856  auto first_or_default(const Container& c, Pred&& pred) -> typename Container::value_type
4857  {
4858  auto it = std::find_if(c.begin(), c.end(), std::forward<Pred>(pred));
4859  return it == c.end() ? typename Container::value_type{} : *it;
4860  }
4861 
4862  template<typename Container>
4863  auto last_or_default(const Container& c) -> typename Container::value_type
4864  {
4865  return c.rbegin() == c.rend() ? typename Container::value_type{} : *c.rbegin();
4866  }
4867 
4868  template<typename Container, typename Pred>
4869  auto last_or_default(const Container& c, Pred&& pred) -> typename Container::value_type
4870  {
4871  auto it = std::find_if(c.rbegin(), c.rend(), std::forward<Pred>(pred));
4872  return it == c.rend() ? typename Container::value_type{} : *it;
4873  }

4888  VERIFY(exec_count == 2);
4889  @endcode
4890  */
4891  template<typename F>
4892  impl::memoizer<F> make_memoized(F fn)
4893  {

4895  }
4896 
4897  /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
4898  /// @brief Basic scope guard - execute some code in guard`s destructor.
4899  /*!
4900  @code
4901  {{
4902  // ...
4903 
4904  auto on_exit = fn::make_scope_guard([&]
4905  {
4906  std::cerr << "Executing clean-up or roll-back...\n";
4907  });
4908 
4909  on_exit.dismiss(); // Cancel if no longer applicable.
4910  }}
4911  @endcode
4912  */
4913  template<typename F>
4914  impl::scope_guard<F> make_scope_guard(F fn)
4915  {
4916  return { std::move(fn), false };
4917  }
4918 
4919  /// @}
4920 
4921 
4922 namespace operators
4923 {
4924  // Why operator % ?
4925  // Because many other libraries overload >> or | for various purposes,
4926  // so in case of compilation errors involving those
4927  // you get an honorable mention of every possible overload in TU.
4928  //
4929  // Also, in range-v3 it is used for composition of views
4930  // rather than a function application, so we want to avoid possible confusion.
4931 
4932  /// @brief `return std::forward<F>(fn)(std::forward<Arg>(arg))`
4933  ///
4934  /// This is similar to Haskell's operator `(&) :: a -> (a -> b) -> b |infix 1|` or F#'s operator `|>`
4935  template<typename Arg, typename F>
4936  auto operator % (Arg&& arg, F&& fn) -> decltype( std::forward<F>(fn)(std::forward<Arg>(arg)) )
4937  {
4938  // NB: forwarding fn too because it may have rvalue-specific overloads
4939  return std::forward<F>(fn)(std::forward<Arg>(arg));
4940  }
4941 
4942  // Note: in operator %= and <<= below we're not returning the original reference
4943  // because the operators are right-to-left associative, so it makes no sense to do it.
4944 
4945  /// @brief `arg = fn::to(Arg{})(std::forward<F>(fn)(std::move(arg)));`
4946  ///
4947  /// `strs %= fn::where([](const std::string& s){ return !s.empty(); }); // drop empty strings`
4948  template<typename Arg, typename F>
4949  auto operator %= (Arg& arg, F&& fn) -> decltype(void(std::forward<F>(fn)(std::move(arg))))
4950  {
4951  // NB: forwarding fn too because it may have rvalue-specific overloads.
4952  // Note: result-type may be not the same as arg, so we
4953  // have to move the elements rather than simply assign.
4954  arg = fn::to(Arg{})(std::forward<F>(fn)(std::move(arg)));
4955  }
4956 
4957  /// @brief End-insert elements of cont2 into cont1 by-move.
4958  /*!
4959  @code
4960  out <<= GetItems();
4961 
4962  // equivalent of:
4963  {{
4964  auto items = GetItems();
4965  for(auto&& item : items) {
4966  out.insert(out.end(), std::move(item));
4967  }
4968  }}
4969  @endcode
4970  */
4971  template<class Container1, class Container2>
4972  auto operator<<=(Container1& cont1,
4973  Container2&& cont2) -> decltype(void(cont1.insert(cont1.end(), std::move(*cont2.begin()))))
4974  {
4975  static_assert(std::is_rvalue_reference<Container2&&>::value, "");
4976  cont1.insert(cont1.end(),
4977  std::make_move_iterator(cont2.begin()),
4978  std::make_move_iterator(cont2.end()));
4979  }
4980 
4981  // Could also take Container2 by value, but taking by rvalue-reference instead
4982  // will preserve the internal storage of the container (instead of it being
4983  // freed here when going out of scope if we took it by value). In some cases
4984  // this may be desirable. So instead having separate overloads for
4985  // Container2&& and const Container2& that will copy elements.
4986 
4987  template<class Container1, class Container2>
4988  auto operator<<=(Container1& cont1,
4989  const Container2& cont2) -> decltype(void(cont1.insert(cont1.end(), *cont2.begin())))
4990  {
4991  cont1.insert(cont1.end(),
4992  cont2.begin(),
4993  cont2.end());
4994  }
4995 
4996  // I would have expected that seq-based input would work with the above overload as well,
4997  // but that is not so - after wrapping into std::make_move_iterator we're getting
4998  // compilation errors about missing operators +,+=,-,-= for the iterator.
4999  // Hence the special overload for seq (it already yields rvalue-references)
5000  template<class Container1, class Gen>
5001  void operator<<=(Container1& cont1, impl::seq<Gen> seq)
5002  {
5003  cont1.insert(cont1.end(), seq.begin(), seq.end());
5004  }
5005 
5006  template<class Container>
5007  void operator<<=(Container& cont, typename Container::value_type el)
5008  {
5009  cont.insert(cont.end(), std::move(el));
5010  }
5011 
5012 } // namespace operators
5013 
5014 } // namespace fn
5015 
5016 } // namespace rangeless

5041 // move-only non-default-constructible type wrapping an int.
5042 // Will use it as our value_type in tests to verify that
5043 // we're supporting this.
5044 struct X
5045 {
5046  int value;
5047 
5048  X(int i) : value{ i }
5049  {}
5050 
5051 #if defined(__GNUC__) && (__GNUC___ >= 5)
5052  X() = delete;
5053 
5054  // We want to test that everything compiles even if the
5055  // type is not default-constructibse, however, with GCC 4.9.3
5056  // that results in
5057  // /opt/ncbi/gcc/4.9.3/include/c++/4.9.3/bits/stl_algobase.h:573:4: error: static assertion failed: type is not assignable
5058  // when calling std::erase or std::rotate on a vector<X>.
5059  //
5060  // So making leaving X default-constructible.
5061 #endif
5062  X(X&&) = default;
5063  X& operator=(X&&) = default;
5064 
5065  X(const X&) = delete;
5066  X& operator=(const X&) = delete;
5067 
5068  operator int&()
5069  {
5070  return value;
5071  }
5072 
5073  operator const int& () const
5074  {
5075  return value;
5076  }
5077 };
5078 using Xs = std::vector<X>;
5079

5518 /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
5519 /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
5520 /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
5521 static void run_tests()
5522 {
5523  using fn::operators::operator%;
5524 
5525 #if 0 // single test
5526 
5527  std::map<std::string, std::function<void()>> tests1{}, tests2{}, test_other{};
5528  test_other["single"] = [&]
5529  {
5530  auto res = Xs{}
5531  % fn::to_seq()
5532  % fn::group_all()
5533  % fn::transform([](Xs v)
5534  {
5535  return (int)v.size();
5536  });
5537  };
5538 
5539 #else // all tests
5540 
5541  std::map<std::string, std::function<void()>>
5542  test_cont{}, test_seq{}, test_view{}, test_other{};
5543 
5544  // make battery of tests where input is a container (Xs)
5545  test_cont = make_tests([](std::initializer_list<int> xs)
5546  {
5547  Xs ret;
5548  for(auto x : xs) {
5549  ret.push_back(X(x));
5550  }
5551  return ret;
5552  });
5553 
5554  // make battery of tests where input is an input-range
5555  test_seq = make_tests([](std::initializer_list<int> xs)
5556  {
5557  Xs ret;
5558  for(auto x : xs) {
5559  ret.push_back(X(x));
5560  }
5561  return fn::to_seq()(std::move(ret));
5562  });
5563 
5564  // make battery of tests where input is a view
5565  test_view = make_tests([](std::initializer_list<int> xs)
5566  {
5567  // will be returning views; will keep the underlying data
5568  // in a static vector.
5569 
5570  static std::vector<Xs> vecs{};

5957  {

5963  it = inputs.end(),
5964  started = false,
5965  flag = false]() mutable
5966  {
5967  if(!started) {
5968  started = true;
5969  it = inputs.begin();
5970  }
5971  return it == inputs.end() ? fn::end_seq()
5972  : (flag = !flag) ? std::move(*it++)
5973  : delim;
5974  });

5988  };

5996  : delim;
5997  });
